VIII

We have tried to show in the foregoing that to impose tariffs on inter-
national trade is generally in the rational interest of single countries for more
than one reason. This does not conflict with the fact that free trade is the best
policy for the universe as a whole. For just as each entrepreneur's competitive
behaviour diminishes the profits of all entrepreneurs, so each single country's
effort to increase its national welfare tends to diminish the welfare of all.

Free trade leads to the best allocation (most efficient utilisation) of the
world's resources, provided that full employment is somehow ensured. It leads
to a distribution of welfare among nations that, if ethically neutral, is at least
based on historically and geographically determined inequalities and not on
inequalities of political and military power. Any corrections of this distribution
that may be considered necessary or just, are better made openly (preferably in
kind), in the form of payments of tribute or assistance, than surreptitiously,
under the cloak of tariffs or barter agreements. That is a better guarantee of
economic efficiency and justice.

But it is not enough to declare the desirability of free trade and trust that
enlightenment will bring it about: nor is it enough to create initial conditions
favourable to it: it must be imposed and enforced. Whether this should be
done with the aid of the more effective sanctions of a new League of Nations,
or through the political prestige of a British Empire, or in any other way, is
beyond the economist's competence to decide. We can only tell that some form
of compulsion is necessary to ensure free trade. The truth of this statement is
attested by the past history of international trade as much as by our rationalisa-
tion of it. Both show that independent states, in possession of their full
sovereignty, will keep on erecting and raising tariffs in order to increase their
share of the world's resources, to achieve fuller employment, and to protect
their growing industries. Of these three aims only the last is likely to be
realised ; the second will generally defeat itself as tariffs are erected all round ;
whereas the first will not only defeat itself but every country will actually be
impoverished as they all raise their tariffs. It is to guard against this general
impoverishment that free trade must be enforced and each country kept from
seeking more than its share of the world's resources. Employment can be
maintained and infant industries subsidised by other means than protection.
This, from a single country's point of view, is probably the cheapest way of
achieving those aims ; but it is against the general interest to let one country
do what would be detrimental to all if generally practised.

(3) The form of the propensity to save function depends on the distribution
of income ; for rich people generally save a larger proportion of their income
than the poor. Hence, we can say that the more unequal is its distribution, the
greater the proportion of the national income which will be saved. A change in
trade policy, therefore, will on this account tend to raise or to lower the level of
employment according as it makes the distribution of income less or more
unequal. This is a purely economic argument in favour of trade policies that
tend to make the distribution of income more equal.

affect that of exports, they always enhance the liquidity of the banking system

will always lead to lower interest rates, provided that the banking system
allows its interest rate policy to be at all influenced by its liquidity. But too

VI.

So far we have been concerned with the theory of tariffs on the classical
assumption of full (or a given level of) employment. We now proceed to con-
sider the effect of tariffs on employment ; such effect to be added to or sub-
tracted from the effects of tariffs on national welfare hitherto discussed. For
an increase in employment increases national welfare in exactly the same way
as a. tariff does when the foreigners' reciprocal demand is inelastic. It increases
the quantity of all goods except that of involuntary idleness, and thus makes
it possible for everybody to be better off than he was before, whatever the
distribution of welfare. Before examining how tariffs affect employment,
however, it will be necessary shortly to recapitulate the theory of employment
in a closed community.

It is generally agreed to-day among economists that it is most convenient
to think of the level of employment as being determined by the equality of
investment and saving. If we consider investment activity in the short period
as a datum—a convention based on the consideration that capital equipment,
having the longest gestation period, is the commodity whose rate of production
is least dependent on present and most irrevocably determined by past
decisions—employment and income must be such as to make saving equal to
investment. The function showing the proportion of income the community
saves out of each level of income is called the propensity to save function. If
its form is approximately linear, the process by which additional investment
generates additional income can be illustrated by an infinite geometric pro-
gression, well known as the theory of the multiplier.

In a closed community saving must equal investment in short-period
equilibrium, because that is the condition for the equality of anticipated and
realised receipts in current production. In an open economy, the condition for
short-period equilibrium is still the equality of anticipated and realised receipts
in domestic current production. But since in the latter case there are two
alternatives to spending on home produced goods: saving, and spending on
imported goods ; and the receipts of domestic producers originate not only in
domestic expenditure but also in exports, it follows that, in an open economy,
the condition for short-period equilibrium is the equality between the sum of
imports and saving and the sum of exports and investment. In other words,
an open economy has no inherent short-run tendency to equate either saving
with investment or exports with imports ; but only to make the discrepancies
in these two equal to each other.! Only to the extent that the central bank
allows changes in its reserves (caused by the export or import surplus) to

Since few goods are inferior, and most goods are substitutes for each
other to some extent, the chances are that if we endeavoured to calculate the
gain in income needed to compensate for the loss of a group of goods by adding

Mr. Kaldor and Professor Hicks have asserted that it is always possible:to
tell whether a given change improves general welfare, even if not all people
gain by it and some lose. The test suggested by them : to see whether it is
possible after the change fully to compensate the losers at a cost to those
favoured that falls short of their total gain, is fundamentally identical with
the first of our two criteria. The objection to using this criterion by itself is that
it is asymmetrical, because it attributes undue importance to the particular
distribution of welfare obtaining before the contemplated change. If the
government had a special attachment to the s/atus quo before the change and
would actually undertake to reproduce that welfare distribution by differential
taxation after the change, then Mr. Kaldor's test would be sufficient. For then,
the economist could regard that particular welfare distribution as the only
relevant one and would be entitled to use it as his sole standard of reference.
But in the absence of such a governmental policy there can be no justification
in attaching greater importance to the welfare distribution as it was before
than as it is after the change.

The economic meaning of this is that the identical change in the composi-
tion of the national income would improve general welfare for some hypothetical
welfare distributions and worsen it for others. Imagine members of a com-
munity divided into two groups according to their preference for goods Y and X
respectively.! Then assume a change that increases the quantity of Y and
diminishes that of X, but leaves the distribution of money income between
our two groups unaffected. From the point of view of individuals, the change
will appear as a shift in relative prices ; which, given the distribution of income,
will be likely to make those with a special preference for Y better off, and those
with a liking for X worse off, than they were before. Assume next that the
members of our first group are rich and those of the second poor. Then the gain
of the first group expressed in money (or in terms of any single commodity)
will be greater than the money equivalent of the loss suffered by the second
group. Therefore, if we so redistributed income as to restore approximately
the initial distribution of welfare, there would be a net gain, making members of
both groups better off than they were before. Conversely, if the people favoured
by the change were poor, and those prejudiced by it were rich, the money
equivalent of the former's gain would be insufficient fully to compensate the
latter's loss, so that a redistribution of income tending to restore the initial
distribution of welfare would result in a net loss of satisfaction for everybody.

What significance are we to attach to this case ? To refrain altogether, as
the classical economists did, from making welfare propositions relating to it,
seems unduly restrictive. It is true that as we have seen such a change would
improve general welfare for some welfare distributions and worsen it for others ;
on the other hand, we are not interested in all possible welfare distributions.
There are only two distributions of welfare that really matter. Those actually
obtaining immediately before and after the change contemplated.? It seems
therefore sufficient to concentrate on these and to investigate how the change
would affect general welfare if it were to leave the distribution of welfare
unaffected and if that were both before and after it, first what it actually is
before, secondly what it actually is after, the change. Whenever these two
comparisons yield identical results, we can make welfare propositions of almost
the same generality and significance as the allocative welfare propositions of
the classical economists; especially since the identical results for the two
welfare distributions imply a strong presumption in favour of the same result
holding for all intermediate welfare distributions as well.

We propose, therefore, to make welfare propositions on the following
principle. We must first see whether it is possible in the new situation so to
redistribute income as to make everybody better off than he was in the initial

III

We have: seen above that allocative welfare propositions are based on the
criterion of economic efficiency. They state that of alternative situations,
brought about by different institutions or courses of policy, one is superior to
the other in the sense that it would make everybody better off for every
distribution of welfare, 7f that were the same in the two situations. This is
different from saying that one situation is actually better than the other from
everybody's point of view, because a change in institutions or policy almost
always redistributes welfare sufficiently not to have a uniform effect on every-
body but to favour some people and prejudice others. It follows from this that
economic welfare propositions cannot as a rule be made independently of
interpersonal comparisons of utility.

It would hardly be satisfactory, however, to confine the economist's value
judgments to cases where one situation is superior to the other from the point
of view of everybody affected. It is doubtful if in practice any choice comes
within this category ; besides, there would not be much point in soliciting the
economist's expert opinion when everybody is unanimous, except in order to
enlighten people as to their true interest.

Favouring an improvement in the organisation of production and exchange
only when it is accompanied by a corrective redistribution of income fully com-
pensating those prejudiced by it might seem to be a way out of the difficulty,
because such a change would make some people better off without making
anyone worse off. For instance, it might be argued that the abolition of the
Corn Laws should not have been advocated by economists in their capacity of
pure economists without advocating at the same time the full compensation of
landowners out of taxes levied on those favoured by the cheapening of corn.
Yet, in a sense, and regarded from a long-run point of view, such propositions
are not independent of value judgments between alternative income distribu-
tions either. For, going out of their way to preserve the existing distribution
of income, they imply a preference for the s/atus quo.

There seem to be two solutions of the problem. First of all, in addition to
admitting his inability to compare different people's satisfaction, the economist
may postulate that such comparisons are impossible, and that therefore there
is nothing to choose between one distribution of income and another. He may
then make value judgments on the sole criterion of efficiency without bothering
about concomitant shifts in the distribution of income, since he considers one
income distribution as good as any other. In this case, however, he cannot
claim that his value judgments are independent of interpersonal utility com-
parisons,-because they depend on the assumption of their impossibility.

The maximum time-rate of price-fall compatible with the stability of the

marginal productivity of capital and the secular rise in market rates of interest,
and thereby to maintain the level of employment in the long run. It is more
likely that even in the case of (limited) price-flexibility, the long-run level of
employment will fall in a progressive economy, although, of course, at a smaller
rate than when prices are perfectly rigid.

It is often said that the contrast between the relatively smooth working
of our economic system during the nineteenth century and the chronic unem-
ployment of the 1920's and '30's is explained by the increasing rigidity of our
price- and cost-structure. While personally I do not think that this factor is
very important, it has been shown above that it is a possible explanation, yet
it does not follow from it that measures aiming at increasing the flexibility of
prices and costs would be the proper remedy. For hand in hand with the
increasing rigidity of prices went another development: the community's
diminishing willingness to bear risk. This tendency manifested itself partly in
the increased care and caution with which investments were planned, and
partly in the shift in investors' tastes from ordinary shares to preferential stock
and fixed-interest-bearing securities. Both these changes were shown above to
make for lesser stability of the system so that the greater rigidity of present-day
prices and costs may well be necessary to maintain the stability of our economy.

Other, and probably more important factors that have contributed to the
spectacular progress and relatively high average level of employment of the
nineteenth century were population growth, the increase in the quantity of
money (in the form of gold rushes and of the development of the means of
payment other than gold), and, possibly, technical advance. Population
growth raises the marginal productivity of capital by diminishing its quantity
relatively to that of labour; it diminishes the propensity to save by lowering
real income per head (owing to the law of non-proportional returns) ; and it
increases the willingness to bear risk by making misinvestments pay.! At the
same time, however, it also tends slightly to raise interest rates by increasing
the transaction demand for money ; but on balance it is likely both to raise the
inducement to invest and to lower the propensity to save, and thereby to raise
the level of employment. The increase in the quantity of money tends to lower
market rates of interest and, if carried further, may also raise prices sufficiently

When we start from a position of perfect competition in related industries,
the only problem which arises is whether new commodities ought to be intro-
duced which were not being produced in the initial position. Each existing
commodity is given its right to exist by the mere fact of its being profitable to
produce it. But when we start from a position where there is an excess of price
over marginal cost in the related industries, the social cost of producing a
particular article is no longer represented by its marginal cost curve. We have
to mark up the marginal cost curve, in the manner described in the last section ;
so that it becomes possible for production to be profitable when the social
surplus accruing from production of the article is negative. The social surplus
— consumers' surplus J- producers' surplus — loss of potential surplus on other
commodities ; this may well be negative, when producers' surplus is positive.

This is the possibility which has been uncovered by the modern theories
of Imperfect Competition ; it is in fact the correct and general statement of
the possibility of loss due to Imperfect Competition. In order to compress it
into the marginal analysis, all the writers on the subject have made simplifica-
tions which are unwarrantable, and to some extent misleading. The different
products of the different firms in an imperfectly competitive industry do
generate consumers' surpluses, by the mere fact that they are different. To
emphasise the differences between the products for the purpose of getting a
downward sloping demand curve for the individual firm, and then to neglect
the differences between the products (irrational preferences !) for the purpose
of neglecting the consumers' surplus, is both inconsistent and practically
dangerous. To neglect the producers! surplus for the purpose of equating
price with average cost imports quite unnecessary difficulties into the theory.
These two simplifications together have been responsible for the quite incorrect
idea that the number of firms in an industry ought always to be reduced when
an industry is imperfectly competitive—an idea which we should at once
recognise as absurd if we were not bemused by diagrams, and whose practical
realisation could only lead to universal monopoly. One may remark, in paren-
thesis, that it is particularly absurd when it is applied (as it often is) to the
problems of retail trade ; in retail trade both the consumers' surpluses (due to
economy of shopping time) and the producers' surpluses (economy of living at
one's work) which are derived from multiplicity of shops are abnormally large,
so that the technical advantages of a concentration policy have to be abnormally
large if there is to be a case for it.

And so one might go on. But enough has perhaps been said to show that
Consumers' Surplus is not a mere economic plaything, a curioswm. It is the
foundation of an important branch of economics, a branch cultivated with
superb success by Marshall, Edgeworth and Pigou, shockingly neglected in the
last twenty years, but urgently needing reconstruction on a broader basis.
Beyond all doubt it is still capable of much further development ; if economists
are to play their part in shaping the canons of economic policy fit for a new age,
they will have to build on the foundation of Consumers' Surplus.

Manchester. J. R. Hicks.

balances can be increased at the expense of commodities as well as at the

to lead to a substitution of cash for both securities and commodities. Thus the
functions of the propensity to consume and to invest appear to have common
parameters with the liquidity preference function and cannot be supposed to
remain unaltered when the latter changes. In consequence an increase in
liquidity preference affects commodity prices and/or employment not only
indirectly via a rise in the rate of interest, but also directly through a down-
ward shift of the demand function for commodities. The recognition of the
fact that the demand for commodities is sympathetic toward shifts in the

If the forward price quoted for any future date does not afford a sufficient
premium over the spot price to cover carrying costs, holders of stocks will
refuse to sell forward at that date. If that applies to all future dates they will
refuse to sell forward at all; they will either sell spot, or will hold their stocks
speculatively uncovered. Such a condition of the market tends to evoke sales
of spot supplies, till the fall in the spot price restores the normal condition in
which every forward price provides a sufficient premium to cover carrying
costs. But this process may be interrupted by a shortage of spot supplies. That
really means that traders' stocks cannot be further reduced except at the cost
of some loss of convenience. The inconvenience may take the form of a lower
minimum holding, involving a greater risk of the trader's operations being
interrupted by an exhaustion of his stock, but is more likely to be the incon-
venience of smaller and more frequent purchases for replenishment. The higher
spot price has the same effect as a rise in the short-term rate of interest on those
traders who hold goods with borrowed money.

It iswhen thisshortage of spot supplies becomes severe enough to outweigh
the entire carrying cost that a "backwardation," or excess of the spot price
over the forward price, appears. Such temporary scarcities are, of course, not

better supplies that justifies either the lower future price or the present release

CAPITAL LEVIES IN WESTERN EUROPE 41

This leaves the alternative of levy by some non-fiscal device, which means in practice
a blocage. No doubt a permanent blocage is less clumsy than a fiscal levy. But unless
the inclusion of non-monetary assets would not materially affect the distribution of the
burden a fiscal levy would appear to be advantageous on equity grounds, except where the
methods of valuation of non-monetary assets are very unsatisfactory. A temporary
blocage is another matter, but this is not generally an appropriate alternative.

Of course, a satisfactory answer to this question can only be given for each individual
case after a detailed examination of its administration, methods of valuation and guesses
about the likely affects of the alternatives. All that is suggested here is that a general case
against the levy on equity grounds, is, in the circumstance of the post-war levies in Western
Europe, difficult to substantiate. Certainly there do not appear to be any a priori grounds
for preferring the alternative to the levies.

CONCLUSIONS

Post war capital levies have been operated in many countries without giving rise to
major difficulties, and in a number of instances they have been productive of substantial
revenues. Their success from these standpoints was greater than anyone would reason-
ably have expected on the basis of earlier experience with this form of taxation.  Amongst
the factors which go to explain this success, the monetary reforms and the existence of
effective systems of exchange control must be assigned a high place.

To evaluate the economic usefulness of these levies is another matter and it is not an
easy task. Each of the anti-inflationary levies made a substantial contribution to the
reduction in liquidity desired by the authorities, but their effects from this standpoint were
rapidly offset by the monetary or budgetary policies which were simultaneously being
pursued. This result emphasises the need to accompany an anti-inflationary levy with a
restrictive credit policy if the levy is to be effective. A capital levy is unlikely to be an
adequate substitute for a restrictive credit policy where excess liquidity exists, although
it is sometimes regarded in this light. It is perhaps best to look at it, at least initially, as a
means of reducing the burden of such a policy. The main merit of the other levies rests
on their ability to combine the fixed assessment basis of the levy with a capacity to restrict
effective demand. In the case of Finland's Second Capital Levy the value of the tax
as an instrument for facilitating a substantial redistribution of real capital was also
important.

Evidently a full evaluation of these levies requires that they should be compared with
the alternative instruments available for achieving the same ends from the threefold
standpoints of administration, economic effects and equity. This article does not pretend
to provide the material for making such a general judgement. It does seem justifiable
to conclude however that if these devices are evaluated not against any ideal alternative,
but rather against the alternatives practically available, then a number of the levies must
be conceded to have considerable merit. In a sense though, any general justification for
these levies has to rest on distributional grounds, although in some instances questions of
incentive may also be relevant. This is because in most cases the alternative devices
available do not appear to be demonstrably inferior to the levy whether they are con-
sidered from the standpoint of administration or from the standpoint of their effects on
the level of effective demand.

Concerning the view that macrotheory has been built up as a parallel or analogy
to microtheory, and that we cannot construct macrotheory without making use of micro-
theory, it may, first of all, be said that this is hardly justified by the history of economic
thought. A great deal of classical theory is macrotheory, and does not depend for its
justification or empirical relevance on micro analogies.! Secondly, although it may well
be admitted that it is possible to construct macrotheory as an analogy to micro theory,
and economists sometimes do so, this is not an argument relevant to the logical structure
of economic theory. After all, to refer to an old problem, while hypotheses may sometimes
in practice be obtained inductively, this in no way validates induction as a form of inference.
In addition, some disaggregated models such as the matrix multiplier have been derived
by way of analogies to aggregated models, but it would scarcely be suggested that the
latter are logically prior or more fundamental than the former. Thirdly, the approach
based on analogies with microtheory seems to mistake the whole purpose of macrotheory
which is to analyse specific problems based on aggregates. Thus the behaviour of con.
sumption relative to national income can be formulated and tested without the apparatu:
of maximizing and allocative theory. Moreover, one may go further and suggest that
microtheory may even be an impediment to the formulation of good hypotheses at the
macro-level. In the case of the acceleration principle, for example, it has been shown
that this may or may not lead to the magnification of fluctuations in net investment relative
to net national income (or net investment of the firm relative to its sales). The ability
to progress beyond pure taxonomy, however, depends on the construction of a complete
model into which are introduced empirical assumptions. In this way, the introduction
of the macro-consumption function (with the usual conditions of diminishing marginal
and average propensities to consume) does, in fact, lead to magnification in a macro-
model.?

An important consequence of this point of view is that a less aggregated analysis
of any problem cannot by itself stand as a criticism or refutation of a more aggregated
analysis. For example, models have been constructed in which investment minus saving
ex ante is equal to the sum of excess demands ex ante in à number of factor and goods
markets. Equilibrium is defined as a situation in which excess demand in every market
is zero, so that equality of investment and saving ex ante is not a sufficient condition for
equilibrium. It is then suggested that this throws doubt on the value of models based of
a straightforward investment-saving approach.5 But this would be so only if, on the one
hand, the investment-saving approach were intended to solve problems related to the
interdependence of markets, and, on the other, the market approach is shown to provide
better answers to the problems for which the theory in terms of investment and saving
was propounded.

Problem

1l. INTRODUCTION

The aggregation problem is concerned with the relationship between macrotheory
and microtheory. Its usual formulation (as set out, for example, by Klein [4, 5], Balderston
and Whitin [1], or Theil [10]) involves a comparison between the predictions obtained
from a large economic model with many equations and variables and a smaller model in
which the variables and parameters are aggregates of those in the larger model. In
particular, it is desirable that the aggregated predictions of the micro model should not
conflict with those of the macro model. A simple example is provided by de Wolff [14].
Assuming that an unambiguous meaning can be attached to the income elasticity of
demand of an individual consumer, he investigates those circumstances in which similar
precision can be attached to the concept when applied to a group of consumers.

In a recent book by Theil [10] it is shown that where a set of linear micro equations
is to be aggregated into a single macro equation, aggregates can always be defined so that
predictions from the micro equations do not contradict those from the macro equation.
Similarly, such *' perfect" aggregation is frequently possible when the micro equations
are non-linear?

Where there are several macro equations to be derived, a less satisfactory state of
affairs prevails. While it is always possible to obtain macro reduced form equations from
linear micro reduced form equations, this situation corresponding to the single macro
equation case, it is rarely possible to obtain macro structural equations in the same way.
The reason for this is that the same micro variables will usually be aggregated differently
in different macro reduced form equations, but to obtain the macro structural equations
it is required that these aggregates be identical?.

The position adopted in this paper is that the attempt to solve the aggregation problem
by means of the definition of indices of micro variables is bound to be unsatisfactory,
and leads to a mistaken view of the relationship between micro and macro theory. Apart
from the possibility of the non-identity of indices*, the present view is unacceptable because

We cannot, therefore, simply define a monopolistic policy by the relationship between
accounting prices and costs, but must always consider the relationship between these
relative to their relationship elsewhere.

The difficulty is, which relationship to use ? Our original choice was the relationship
between price and marginal cost in some industry chosen at random, but, as McManus
correctly points out, the status of this industry is higher than that of a mere numeraire.
In effect, the * hidden assumption ' for which McManus searches but does not correctly
locate is that we have assumed it is to the price of the n'th commodity that the monopolist's
reactions are geared. This is a useful enough assumption in many models—the z'th
commodity might, for example, be a competitively produced good which is the chief
substitute for the monopolist's output—but it is not general. Perhaps the answer in the
general case is to assume the monopolist's relationship between price and marginal cost to
all other industries, the functional relationship being ultimately determined by demand
conditions. This will certainly confront us with some complex analysis.

Our intent in writing the original article was to indicate that piecemeal application
of single Paretian welfare conditions in a situation in which not al] such conditions could
be satisfied might well decrease, rather than increase, welfare. McManus's comments
certainly add strength to our original contention.

CURRENCY AREAS

The sterling and dollar areas have remained relatively homogeneous and stable but
the composition of even these was not entirely constant.

The sterling area included throughout the period all colonial possessions and dependen-
cies of the United Kingdom except the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and Palestine ; in addition,
Australia, New Zealand, India, Pakistan, Ceylon, South Africa, Ireland, Iceland, Iraq and
Burma. Egypt and the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan left the Sterling Area in July 1947, Palestine
and Jordan in February 1948, Jordan (though not Israel) rejoining the area in July 1950.
The Faroe Islands were part of the sterling area until November 1948 and Libya has been
a member since January 1952.

The dollar area, in addition to Canada! the United States and her dependencies,
included throughout Liberia,! the Philippines and the following thirteen Central and South
American countries : Columbia, Costa Rica, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador,
Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, El Salvador, Venezuela.
Bolivia became a member of the dollar area in July 1947, Chile was a member from July
1947 to July 1948 and Peru from July 1947 to August 1948. For purposes of the statistical
analysis imports from the last two countries were included in the dollar totals for 1948
only. Uruguay was in the dollar area only from July 1947 to March 1948 ; since this
period did not include June 30th in either year, Uruguay is not treated as in the dollar area
in 1947 or 1948.

What has been termed the rest of the world is a heterogeneous collection of countries,
towards which import policy was generally far from uniform. From 1949/50 onwards,
however, it contained one major component, the relaxation area, which enjoyed more or
less uniform treatment, but as even this area was growing in size, figures for different
years would not be strictly comparable.?

As it stands, the *' rest of the world " group is relatively constant in size, being affected
only by the minor changes in composition of the sterling and dollar areas already mentioned.

(a) On supply grounds : Licences to import essentials from areas (e.g., the dollar
area) from which they are not on Open Licence are considered ad hoc in the light of advice
from a responsible government department.

(b) In relation to end use : Applications for licences to import machinery (and certain
dollar materials) are considered individually in relation to end-use and alternative sources
ofsupply. The issue of licences to import goods either for re-export in the form imported
(REX licence) or for ultimate export after processing (UX licences), depends largely on the
net foreign exchange earnings.

(c) By quotas : In some cases quotas are established fixing a limit (by quantity or
value) to total imports of a particular commodity for a particular period : sometimes
these apply to one source only (bilateral quotas), sometimes to a large number of sources
together (global quotas). Within these totals, licences may be allocated to individual
importers in various ways. "The most usual method is to share them out among established
importers in proportion to their share of trade in some specified past period when the
imports concerned were not subject to restriction ; (in some cases, this had to be pre-war).

(i) Bilateral quotas have generally been established under bilateral trade negoti-
ations largely as a concession to the exporting country, which has furthermore some-
times been granted the right to administer the allocation of the quota. This applied
in particular to the ** special hardship quotas " granted to those O.E.E.C. countries
which had suffered exceptionally from the British deliberalisation of 1951/2, and
also to licences under the Token Import Scheme. In such cases an import licence is
issued automatically to the British importer who can produce the appropriate certifi-
cate from his foreign supplier. Licences issued in respect of trade agreement quotas
normally have the validity of the period covered by the agreement.

(ii).Global quotas were introduced on a large scale in respect of those commodities
originally liberalised in 1949 and 1950 which were deliberalised during the 1951/2
balance of payments crisis. Quotas mostly related to the whole *' relaxation area "'
and were announced for six months at a time ; applications for licences had to be
made within specified time limits and the licences were normally valid for the period
of the quota (with possible extensions of three months). Only a few of these global
quotas remain at the present time, most of the goods to which they were applied having
been subsequently ** reliberalised ''.

AI items subject to specific licences, however allocated, must be regarded as subject
to quantitative control from the sources for which such individual licences are required.

(4) BLock LicENCES

These were a way of regulating imports, now largely superseded, which bore a super-
ficial resemblance to open individual licences, but were in fact rather a form of restriction
by quota. A limit was placed on total imports, but individual importers obtained licences
permitting them to import the commodity in question freely from the specified source or
sources until the overall limit was reached. All imports and commitments had to be
reported at regular intervals and all licences were withdrawn as soon as the limit was reached
(or expected to be reached on the basis of outstanding commitments). This system was
applied to certain horticultural goods and to chocolate confectionery and biscuits in 1949/51.
Despite the temporary illusion of freedom, it was clearly a form of restriction by quota,
the method of allocating licences being ** first come, first served "'.

The alternative methods of calculation are more directly concerned with measuring
the cost of living of typical households. They are all more complicated numerically than
the conventional method and would raise problems in devising efficient estimation pro-
cedures (for example, is it better to estimate the democratic weights by calculating o and 5
and then applying equation (7), or is the direct method preferable ?). A compromise
along the following lines is, however, worth considering. If it were explicitly recognised
that the index is to refer to a household with a '* median standard of living ", the sample
of household budgets that are to provide the Weights could be confined to a fairly narrow
range of incomes and household sizes. Within these ranges, any variations in expenditure
between households would largely be due to random elements, and very little of the vari-
ation would be correlated with income and family size ; a simple (conventional) averaging

There has been a good deal of discussion about the ways in which countries with high
incomes can help in the development of those with lower per capita incomes. But a low
average income is not the only distinguishing feature of underdeveloped countries and to
concentrate on this one feature may deflect attention from the problems associated with
regional income disparities such as exist in most parts of tropical Africa and in other
underdeveloped areas. Regional disparities in income were as conspicuous in England
before the 19th century as they are in Africa to-day and since they are now much smaller in
England it may be that they automatically disappear with economic growth. But this
should not be taken for granted : the experience of the past decade in Uganda, a period
of very rapid advance albeit a short one from which to generalize, gives no ground for
optimism. Regional disparities are obviated where there is mobility, but there are political
and economic factors in most parts of Africa which inhibit the permanent movement of
people from the poorer to the richer regions of a country. There would be fewer poor in
Southern Italy if there were more employment opportunities in the North, but it cannot be
taken for granted that an acceleration of economic development in Buganda would auto-
matically enhance incomes in the other regions or bring about a permanent resettlement
in Buganda. An increase in average income in Uganda brought about by an acceleration
of economic development in Buganda might create as many internal problems and strains
as it would solve. A tax policy which aimed deliberately to reduce regional disparities in
income per head might be as important to smooth development as measures to promote

of capital gains is to reduce the discrimination against risk bearing inherent in income
tax ".! I still believe that there is a presumption to this effect, and that a British type
income tax, whatever its defects from the point of view of equity, is less discouraging to
risk bearing than a more comprehensive tax which includes realized capital gains in taxable

gains. But in view of Messrs. Musgrave and Domar's findings with regard to the effect
of a tax on Accrued Income with full loss offsets I no longer believe that this conclusion
necessarily follows. Since a tax on Accrued Income lacks the discriminating features of

effects on risk-taking than an expenditure tax. This latter conclusion also casts some doubt

which gives meaning to the concept of profit maximisation ; it is the absence of competition
which is often assumed to lead to its abandonment. The question is how consistently
and generally the forces of competition are overcome in imperfect markets.

Competition must be understood not only as existing competition but also as potential
competition. Inter-firm rivalry may be limited by price agreements but these are notorious-
ly short-lived and there is little evidence of collusion on non-pirice competition. Moreover,
a rigid price is quite consistent with profit maximisation in that each seller believes that
an independent price policy will result in greater losses than gains. There is little evidence,
too, that a low price policy by established firms will be successful in inhibiting potential
competitors. The only certain and positive deterrent to entry is the presence in the
market of energetic and progressive firms which are obviously exploiting all the possi-
bilities. In the case of large firms external competition is reinforced by internal pressures.
Top executives can seldom afford to relax for long or new men will take their places.

Limited capital resources and uncertainty may make entrepreneurs cautious. For
example, the possession of liquid resources is essential but this consideration assumes far
greater importance for small firms than for large firms and is likely to be achieved by a
policy of short run profit maximisation. Borrowing on a large scale may involve loss of
control but profit maximisation must be understood as maximisation of one's own profits
and not those of anyone else. Uncertainty may lead to conservative policies but risks
must be taken from time to time if the firm is to maintain its market position. The
entrepreneur can never be sure that the risks he forswears will not be undertaken by others.
Investment is, after all, not gambling but action taken on the basis of informed knowledge.

In the absence of any objective test or criterion the answer to the question whether
entrepreneurs maximise profits must lie in an examination of the market environment in
which they work. To replace profit maximisation by utility maximisation is to render the
analysis meaningless and even misleading. "We are in no position to assess the subjective
probability distributions in the minds of entrepreneurs or to know what is the utility of
money to them. "The one consistent and general influence upon entrepreneurs which the
economist is in a position to assess with any accuracy is the influence of competition. It
is suggested that this influence must always work in the direction of maximum profits.

IV

On constructing both aggregates and sector accounts, we quite clearly found that the
latter required very much more work than the former ; in fact, as we have demonstrated,
often it was statistically impossible to derive reasonable data on sector sales and purchases,
whilst fairly easy to estimate net output.

This meant that input-output analysis must be of a very great potential use to justify the
expenditure of large statistical resources on it. But, at least in Tanganyika, uses at present
seem to be slight. For the lack of interdependence we suspected was amply confirmed.
Many flows estimated after considerable work were negligible. Others could only be
very roughly quantified. And above all, a very high proportion of the elements in the
matrix were blank.

shall not comment further on this aspect. Perhaps I may be allowed, however, to add
two points on the practical issue.

Professor Shoup, with the help of his numerical illustration (p.), argues that, when
the point of impact is shifted from buyer to seller, the speculative buyer will raise his offer
price by just the amount of the tax, because he will then obtain the same yield as before
on his speculative instrument. I agree in principle, but it seems to me worth pointing out
that it is a very nice calculation of yields which leads to this result. In terms of Professor
Shoup's numerical illustration, the speculator who buys at $80 and sells at $80 will get
5 per cent on his money. If he bought at $79 and sold at $79 he would get 5:06 per cent.
The difference in yield must seem very small to someone not primarily interested in yield
considerations. In my earlier note, I was clearly not justified in arguing that the presence
of speculators would frustrate the rise in share price as a result of the change in point of
impact. Nevertheless, it would seem reasonable to hold that the speculator will not be
very important in determining the market's reaction to the change—or, perhaps more
correctly, that it will be his guess about the reaction of the rest of the market that will be
important. And if the speculators are ready to acquiesce in the reactions of the rest of
the market, then the relative strength in the market of the tax-exempt dealers will be some-
what enhanced, though I certainly would not pretend that this is very great.

The second point is perhaps more important. In my original note, I argued that
the authorities could achieve a rough and ready capital gains tax by raising stamp duties
in times of high market values, provided the incidence of the tax was squarely on the seller.
Now it seems to me clear, once again from Professor Shoup's very helpful numerical
illustration, that the incidence of the tax is indeed on the seller, whatever the point of
impact. There seems to be therefore a prima facie case for a policy of this kind. If the
case were accepted, would there be any value in shifting the point of impact from buyer
to seller ? I still think it would be a sensible thing to do : for, if the taxation of capital
gains is regarded as just, justice must not only be done but also be seen to be done.

III

The conclusions of this paper can be summarised briefly. Its basic contention is
that the amount of money which people desire to hold as a store of wealth depends not
only on the rate of interest but also upon the total amount of wealth available. As the
stock of idle money is part of that wealth changes in this stock may lead to changes in the
desire to hold money.

It is useful to distinguish between demand curves for money (drawn on the assumption
of constant wealth) and interest-reaction curves (drawn on the assumption of changing
amounts of money, and, hence, wealth). The former shows the reaction of the rate of
interest to changes in the quantity of money effected by open-market operations ; the
latter shows the reaction of the rate of interest to ceteris paribus changes in the quantity
of money. The two curves will coincide if the marginal propensity to hold money (X) is

Cost inflation and demand inflation in their pure forms exist only in models VI and IX
respectively. In the other models the inflation is a complex mixture of the two factors.
Basically there are two types of plans which may be in excess of real opportunities to meet

extremely difficult to isolate the two elements, but the terms do have use as indicating the

IX. CONSUMER SOVEREIGNTY

What becomes of the concept of consumer sovereignty for dynamic decision-making
problems? To the extent that consumer sovereignty is one of our values, ought we to
allow people to behave imprudently? Should we permit them the strategy of precom-
mitment ?—e.g., should a man be allowed to sell himself into bondage for the sake of an
immediate gratification of desires ?! What ought to be our view of the irrevocable trust,
especially if the maker tries to revoke it? At which date should sovereignty inhere in the
maker? And ought we to instruct people to substitute a log-linear discount function for
the true one ? If so, should the constant K be selected so that the derivatives of the log-
linear function and the true one are equal at / — « ? Why should this be the appropriate
value ?

My view is that these questions are difficult to answer mainly because consumer
sovereignty has no meaning in the context of the dynamic decision-making problem. The
individual over time is an infinity of individuals, and the familiar problems of interpersonal
utility comparisons are there to plague us. The interpersonal aspect of the intertemporal
problem becomes clear if we think of a similar problem involving a family of brothers
where each has a utility functional depending not only on his own utility but upon a weighted
sum of the utilities of all of them. Suppose the oldest brother always has the power to
allocate the annual proceeds of an estate, but with it being foreknown that each year one
brother will die off, the oldest next. The shifting of the discount function of the family head
gives rise to the danger of inconsistent planning ; and the family head of the moment may
consider the alternative strategies of (a) an irrevocable trust, or (5) playing his favorites
extra heavily now knowing that they will be out of favor at a later date. What can the
detached view of consumer sovereignty be in this context !

Pigou? and others have regarded ** myopia " as an excuse for state intervention in
determining allocations over time (investment). But on what basis ought the state to
make these decisions ? Ramsey? contended that all weights should be equal; but at
least for those problems involving the allocation of a limited stock of goods over time
(i.e., the problem of ** conservation "), this proposal becomes meaningless if one contem-
plates future generations ad infinitum.

More questions have been raised here than I am prepared to answer ; but somewhat
out of practical considerations I would suggest the following : The individual can probably
do as good a job as the state or any other agency in determining allocations for himself
as of future dates, provided the future dates include none which are proximate. That is
to say that I would have confidence in the judiciousness of a person to-day, if he is not
ignorant of future facts, to decide how much to save and how much to spend for the rest
of his life, starting a couple of years from now. | Mr. Smith is probably in as good a position
to evaluate the relative importance of the Mr. Smith of 1960 and the Mr. Smith of 1970
as anybody else, and I would therefore permit him, in the absence of risk and uncertainty,
to precommit his future allocations provided the period of precommitment did not begin for
a couple more years. The real decisions to worry about are those where an immediate
or proximate satisfaction is gained at the expense of still-more-future costs.  Precom-
mitment may be regarded as either good or evil depending upon whether the period of
precommitment begins now or later.

VI. TWO STRATEGIES IN THE FACE OF INCONSISTENCY

An individual who because he does not discount all future pleasures at a constant
rate of interest finds himself continuously repudiating his past plans may learn to distrust
his future behaviour, and may do something about it. Two kinds of action are possible.
(1) He may try to precommit his future activities either irrevocably or by contriving a
penalty for his future self if he should misbehave. This we call the strategy of precommit-
ment. (2) He may resign himself to the fact of intertemporal conflict and decide that his
* optimal" plan at any date is a will-o'-the-wisp which cannot be attained, and learn to
select the present action which will be best in the light of future disobedience. This we
call the strategy of consistent planning. —'T'hese possibilities will be discussed in order.

l. The Strategy of Precommitment. 'To-day it will be rational for a man to jettison
his * optimal " plan of yesterday, not because his tastes have changed in any unexpected
way nor because his knowledge of the future is different, but because to-day he is a different
person with a new discount function—the old one shifted forward in time. Yet it is also
rational for the man to-day to try to ensure that he will do tomorrow that which is best
from the standpoint of to-day's desires. Unpleasant things which to-day we want to do
sometime in the future are continually put off until tomorrow (the *' mafiana effect ^")
unless we can find some way of precommitting ourselves to actually doing the task tomorrow.
Consequently, we are often willing even to pay a price to precommit future actions (and
to avoid temptation). Evidence of this in economic and other social behaviour is not
difficult to find. It varies from the gratuitous promise, from the familiar phrase *' Give
me a good kick if I don't do such and such " to savings plans such as insurance policies
and Christmas Clubs which may often be hard to justify in view of the low rates of return.
(I select the option of having my annual salary dispersed to me on a twelve- rather than on a
nine-month basis, although I could use the interest!) Personal financial management
firms, such as are sometimes employed by high-income professional people (e.g., actors),
while having many other and perhaps more important functions, represent the logical
conclusion of the desire to precommit one's future economic activity. Joining the army
is perhaps the supreme device open to most people, unless it be marriage for the sake
of *' settling down." And, of course, regretting either course later on (at least for the
moment) is to be expected, for otherwise precommitment would have had no purpose.
The worker whose income is garnished chronically or who is continually harassed by
creditors, and who, when one oppressive debt is paid, immediately incurs another is
commonly precommitting. There is nothing irrational about such behaviour (quite the
contrary) and attempts to default on debts are simply the later consequences which are to
be expected. Inability to default is the force of the precommitment.

What needs to be explained is not that people do precommit their future actions, but
that the practice is not still more wide-spread. The reason it is not, I believe, is because
of the presence of risk and uncertainty, both as to future tastes and future opportunities.
Because of risk and uncertainty, people are also willing to pay for options permitting them
a greater range of choice at future dates! and this is of overwhelming importance, especially
as it affects the detailed aspects of future behaviour.

2. The Strategy of Consistent Planning. Since precommitment is not always a feasible
solution to the problem of intertemporal conflict, the man with insight into his future
unreliability may adopt a different strategy and reject any plan which he will not follow
through. His problem is then to find the best plan among those that he will actually
follow.

SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION

In my review of the achievements of the C.D.C. during the period 1948-54, I indicated
the sort of answers which British policy makers have given in practice to our initial set
of questions : To what extent should a development corporation undertake projects in
partnership with private enterprise and local governments ? Under what conditions
should such a corporation undertake the management of development projects directly ?
What test or tests should the development corporation apply in selecting projects? And
should a development corporation finance projects solely by means of loans to private
enterprise and colonial government authorities ?

The review of the Corporation's operations has revealed how the C.D.C. has attempted
to answer the questions raised in the preceding paragraph : (1) Since 1952 association
with private enterprise and/or local colonial governments has been a normal requirement
for capital sanction for all new C.D.C. undertakings. (2) Prior to 1951, the Board of the
C.D.C. managed directly most of the Corporation's projects. After that date, '* deliberate
policy was to look for experienced private enterprise partners to share in investment and
management."! (3) The Corporation was supposed to act for financial purposes as a
commercial concern—to become self-supporting '* taking one year with another." And (4)
the Corporation committed by the end of 1954 approximately 30 per cent of its total capital
in the form of loans—ostensibly to cover '* some part of overheads and abortive pilot
schemes and investigations."?

On the basis of the information I have been able to examine, I do not think that it is
possible to dismiss in one bold stroke the Corporation's £10 million loss as the result of
inattention or laxity in administering the financial and other provisions of the Overseas
Resources Development Act, especially since, as I have attempted to show, the provisions
of the Act are subject to more than one interpretation. And during the initial period
1948-50, no clear and concise criterion for capital sanction was provided either in the
Overseas Resources Act or by the responsible Ministers in Parliament. The Board's

A NOTE ON THE COLONIAL DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION 231

colonial governments are therefore not well equipped to undertake them,! so that '* public
enterprise " is needed. The avowed purpose for which the C.D.C. was set up was that of
** improving the standard of living of the colonial peoples by increasing their productivity
and wealth ".? But it was to do this within the limits imposed by the requirement to
break-even in the longer-run, and it was also to keep the dollar shortage in mind.? This
may be a ** vagueness of the mandate ". One may, perhaps, question the compatibility
of the first two requirements, and the relevance of the third (the colonies being the main
contributor to the sterling area dollar pool). But there seems nothing which invites failure
of the projects undertaken.

The failures, it seems to me, have resulted from a combination of managerial incom-
petence and of the high risks inevitably attaching to untried ventures in the colonies, though
these two elements are in practice not easy to separate. Incompetent management is of
two kinds : the people responsible for the carrying-out of particular projects doing the
wrong thing ; the people responsible for selecting the projects making too optimistic an
assessment of the risks, and doing so on the basis of inadequate investigation. Deficiencies
of both these kinds existed in full measure, and are well illustrated by the story of the
Gambia poultry-farming scheme. It may be that the atmosphere of 1948 was conducive
to an urge for speed and a heavy discounting of risks, although the Corporation had ex-
pressed its intention '* to avoid all embracing and grandiose economic development plans ".
But it was surely right to accept Bagehot's precept that '* caution is the life of banking,
but venture is the life of commerce ". To blame the failures on ** vagueness of the mandate"
or on the financial rules puts things the wrong way round. And it is relevant in this con-
nection to emphasise that the failures were not merely financial (an inability to break-even)
but physical (no eggs and dead chickens).

The real part played by the break-even rule was to compel a sharp contraction in the
growth, and a change in the character of the Corporation's activities once large sums
of money had been lost early-on through bad. management. The Corporation had itself
fully appreciated that it would need, on some of its undertakings, to earn more than what
I have called the modest return to be earned overall : '* it hopes and expects that some of
its undertakings will make substantial yields in order to counterbalance low yields and
losses ". But when large losses were experienced in the early stages, venture had to give
way to caution. In an effort to fulfil its financial obligations the Corporation had to
eschew risks, to cut its losses, and to concentrate on well-paying projects. Hence the
changes which Mr. Wicker describes : increasing participation with private capital ;
increasing importance of debenture loans as a form of financial participation by C.D.C.
The Corporation became something very different from its original conception.

It seems probable that if the Corporation had started more cautiously, and had selected
projects which, though small, were a financial success, nothing would have been heard
of the vagueness of the mandate or of the difficulties inherent in the rules under which the
Corporation operated. The difficulties would have been there, but they would have been
concealed. They were brought into prominence only by the early failures, which were
themselves the result of quite other causes. However, a less venturesome policy would
have brought its own problems, for it would no doubt have been asked whether the oper-
ations of the Corporation were not too limited to do much good for the colonies.

Theory of Capital—A Reply

As far as I can understand Professor Solow's note, it does not touch upon the problem
of capital, but is concerned rather with how to treat non-homogeneous natural resources,
for instance, varieties of Marshall's meteoric stones.? His C, and C, are two kinds of
equipment, but nothing is said about the time which it takes to produce them (gestation
period) or the period over which they are expected to be useful (service life). It is no
argument to dismiss a problem as antiquated until it has either been satisfactorily solved
or shown to be uninteresting.

In my opinion Professor Solew is barking up the wrong tree in seeking either the
problem or the solution amongst index numbers. Let us postulate a world in which
there is only one kind of machine, and let us abstract from working capital. Then the
problem with which Professor Solow is concerned evaporates. Now compare two machines.
If one is older than the other and has a shorter prospective remaining service life, its value
is less, and the difference in value varies with the rate of interest.

Next, compare two machines exactly alike in all respects (including age) except that
one is drawn from an economy with a higher product-wage rate. The value of the two
machines is different, and the investment required to create them is different. A difference
in value remains if we deflate them by the wage rate (obtaining what I have called *' real
capital " or capital in terms of labour time), for in two economies with different product-
wage rates the rate of profit and therefore the rate of interest are different (under the
assumptions on which the argument is set out). I am sorry to have given the impression
that ** it does not seem to bother " me that two exactly similar pieces of equipment may
represent different quantities of accumulation. I was trying precisely to show what there
is to be bothered about.

Again, if the wage rate has altered during the life time of a machine, its historic cost
and its reproduction cost differ.

Finally, two machines, though physically alike may require different quantities of
labour to produce or to operate them (because of technical progress).

None of these questions can be dealt with in terms of an index of physical equipment,
and each of them is important for the analysis of distribution and of capital accumulation.

To turn now to some of the criticisms which are rather more specific to my paper.
(1) Mr. Davis objects to my use of the concept of an industry on the grounds that such an
entity is, in practice, indefineable in terms of either technological similarity or substitu-
tibility.| But, in the simplest form, the concept of an industry is merely a way of stating
that any particular firm, is, in most respects, compelled to give the policies of other firms
very great weight in forming its own. Whether the firms it must watch are the producers
of close substitutes, or technologically similar products, is not really very important ;
nor is it important just where the line is drawn in our theory. As long as the firm does in
practice act as though a defineable industry existed we are justified in having introduced
the concept. The fact that it requires refinement to apply to particular cases does not remove
its advantages.

(2) Mr. Davies suggests that it is anomalous that consumers who are *' largely price
conscious " can be appealed to by means of sales expenditure and product variation.?
But it does in fact appear to be common to seek these '* advantages " as long as no price
is attached to them.

(3) Mr. Davies finds some difficulty in my assumption that. all firms may maximize
their profits, while only the price leader (i.e., the firm willing to accept the lowest price)
will be able to obtain the highest possible profits. "The difference is that the non-leaders
maximize profit subject to the constraint that price is selected for them by another firm.
The leader is under no such constraint : he selects the price to suit himself. The situation
s stable because those who are dissatisfied with it cannot raise their prices without losing
goodwill, whereas lowering prices still further will, by hypothesis, make them less com-
fortable than they already are.

Finally, Mr. Davies is doubtful whether theory has any role at all to play in unravelling
so complex a picture. Whether or not he is right will, ultimately, only be revealed by
patient application of both theoretical and empirical approaches. Butit would seem prema-
ture to abandon the attempt to see certain genera] rules underlying business conduct simply
because the categories employed by theorists do not find exact parallels in the real world.
Economic theory is, after all, a tool of research and not a body of settled knowledge,
and in no field is this more true than in the theory of the firm. It is the task of the applied
economist to adapt the tools provided by the theorist (often perforce the same man!)
to his particular problem, and it would be foolhardy for the theorist to usurp that function.

6. We have reached the point where a summary of our assumptions and conclusions
would be in order. We asserted that if merchants maximise their expected income,
subject to the constraint that the probability that their actual net income falls below
a disaster level should not exceed a certain value, then under certain conditions they
will either hold cash, hold a combination of short-hedged and unhedged stocks, or a
combination of long-hedged commitments and unhedged stocks. In order to find these
conditions we showed that the probability constraint could be approximated by means
of the Tchebycheff inequality without making any assumptions about the form of the
probability distribution. We are able to reach our conclusions in terms of the second
order moments of the probability distribution of prices of spots and futures. In addition,
we argued that the forward price will always equal the spot price plus carrying costs,
and that the futures price will never be greater than the spot price plus carrying costs.
This permitted us to conclude that the expected gain from a long hedge is the negative
of the expected gain from a short hedge.

The detailed conclusions are as follows :

(a) If we expect the spot price and the basis to move in the same direction, then
we will hold short-hedged and unhedged stocks only if we expect both actions to be
profitable. The basis and the spot price will move together if the futures price and the
spot price move in opposite directions.

(b) If we expect the spot price and the basis to move in opposite directions, then
we will hold unhedged stocks and long-hedging commitments if we expect both actions
to be profitable. The spot price and the basis will move in opposite directions when the
futures price and the spot price move in the same direction.

(c) We will hold short-hedged and unhedged stocks when one of these actions is
expected to be unprofitable if the basis and the spot price are expected to move in
opposite directions. Hence we would expect short-hedged stocks and unhedged stocks
to occur simultaneously during the part of the year when no new stocks are expected
to be forthcoming (when the spot price and the futures price will move together).

(d) Similarly we will hold unhedged stocks and long-hedging commitments when
one of these is expected to be unprofitable when the basis and the spot price move in
the same direction. Generally this occurs when the spot and futures prices move in
opposite directions. This is most common in that part of the crop year when new
supplies are expected to be forthcoming.

(e) We will hold only one type of commitment when it is expected to be very
profitable with respect to the other.

The Conservative party had not expressed any intention of reversing the Labour govern-
ment's policy concerning overseas trade and the balance of payments. When in office,
for the first year or so which concern us here, there was no major change of policy in this
field, which might have made the plan irrelevant. Moreover, had there been such a change
of policy, it would not necessarily follow that the plan would forthwith have ceased to be
significant. It is the thesis of this article to suggest that if the plan and its virtual achieve-
ment have significance, it is to show that the economy cannot be directed quickly towards
any particular end. If it takes a year or two to induce the necessary alterations in policy,
and make them effective in the behaviour of firms and individuals, it is likely to take at
least as long for a political decision to change the policy to become effective. Fortunately
for our present purpose, the change of Government came late enough before the plan-year
1952/53 to make the possibility of a major change of policy of little importance.

To summarise then, the only conclusion that can be drawn from the evidence is that
the success of the Long Term Programme, our only 4-year plan, can at present be neither
proved nor disproved. To argue either way, it is necessary to make non-verifiable
assumptions. The assumptions are likely to seem plausible and justified or not according
to the political opinions, knowledge, experience or prejudice of the holders. At least
it can be said that the evidence does not show any prima facie case for the anti-planners
or the cynics.

One conclusion arising clearly from this study is that if planning of this kind is to be
taken seriously it should be more carefully and precisely formulated. If we are interested
in plans we must be interested in their results. 1t is only possible to discover the results
at all exactly if somewhere (not necessarily all of it for publication) there is an account of
exactly what the plan meant.

A more important inference from the somewhat surprising success of the plan, if
success be conceded, is that the distinction between planning the real, and relatively stable,
components of the economy needs to be distinguished more clearly and explicitly from the
monetary, and unstable, components. At worst, the distinction might help to make the
meaning or limits of plans more clearly understood ; at best, it might help towards making
plans more effective. Having distinguished the more stable and predictable elements,
a plan for them should allow a longer time for its operation than has so far been
customary.

5. CONCLUSION

The general conclusion seems to be that, if population is growing, accumulation
of capital has strictly limited powers of raising real wages, in the absence of technical
progress. Under constant returns, with a constant fraction of national income accu-
mulated, it is possible for labour, capital and national income all to increase at the
same rate, maintaining a constant level of real wages. But in order to increase real
wages, capital must increase faster than labour. This entails a rising accumulation-
fraction, which cannot, however, increase indefinitely, since there is an upper limit to
the proportion of its national income that any community can accumulate. Under
diminishing returns, capital must increase faster than labour in order to keep real
wages from falling (let alone raise them) ; except in the improbable case where an
increase in both labour and capital is accompanied by a fall in the amount of rent
(even so, rent cannot become negative). In order that capital may increase faster than
labour, the accumulation-fraction must continually rise, as in the previous case. Under
certain circumstances (such as the existence of rather odd kinds of national-income
function) this increase in the accumulation-fraction may be postponed. If population
grows at a diminishing rate, it is possible that the accumulation-fraction, even if it
rises, may approach asymptotically an upper limit that is practically possible. These
general propositions may be qualified in particular cases ; but it appears probable
that these qualifications will cease to apply with very high rates of capital growth.

All these limitations on the raising of real wages can be removed if we postulate a
sufficiently high rate of technical progress. Thus, technical progress is a necessary
condition for a permanent and continuous increase in real wages. (This conclusion is
expressed in terms of real wages. Similar propositions would hold good of real income
per head. Even if we assume that the State has an unlimited power to redistribute
real income, we cannot escape the conclusions reached here.)

The compatibility of the present theory with others is perhaps less important
than its possibilities as a. fruitful tool of analysis. A convincing demonstration of its
employment must await another occasion, but a brief account of some of its qualities
can be given. Firstly, the basis of the theory is essentially competitive ; it can be
used to show how a man should strive to scale the social ladder or how a firm should
attempt to maintain its predominance in an industry. The man and the firm do not
maximise utility and profits in a vacuum, but condition their actions according to
both their present status in their respective societies and their expectations about the
collective results of their rivals' activities. Secondly, the theory is flexible because we
are free to vary the quality or quantity on which an individual's rank in a given society
is deemed to depend and to re-draw the boundaries of this society according to the
problem in hand. The relevant rank may depend on income, wealth, or marks in an
examination, while the society may be co-extensive with a nation, a village, an
industry, or a profession. Thirdly, the theory explains a great variety of behaviour.
It tells us why small firms must take risks if they want to get on and why large firms
are likely to avoid doing so. Used in conjunction with a simple model applicable to
agriculture, it indicates the degree of crop diversification desirable with large holdings
and explains why smallholders may concentrate on a single crop, the nature of the
crop varying again with the size of holding. It shows under what circumstances some
land may be left idle.

Lastly, but not least in importance, the theory is based on a principle that is
simple and easy to understand. The great advantage of profit maximisation is that its
implications are easily intelligible ; perhaps for this reason there is considerable
reluctance' to abandon the principle even when its limited applicability has been
disclosed. The idea of a firm attempting to secure the highest position in the hierarchy

CONCLUDING REMARKS

On page 1 it was mentioned that this geometrical analysis can be derived from
an ordinary three-dimensional model with the three goods measured along three
recti-inear axes. The two-dimensional point price lines, the money price lines, the
guide lines and the M.P.I.C.s are then projections on to the Oxy plane of, respectively,
the point budget planes, the money budget plane at various levels of z, the inter-
sections of pairs of money budget planes, and the curves formed by the intersection of
the various indifference surfaces with a money budget plane.

The technique may prove useful in economic fields other than that of rationing.
For instance, in the theory of consumer's choice without rationing it can illustrate two
aspects which cannot be dealt with in the usual two-good model. These are comple-
mentarity and the theorem that a group of goods behaves as a single good for pro-
portional price changes.

The theory of rationing is but a simple extension of the theory of consumer's
choice without rationing. It is more difficult to analyse satisfactorily by geometry, but
the additional complexity is due more to the need to consider a three-good model
than to the introduction of an extra budget constraint. In this paper, the three goods
are treated asymmetrically as regards the indifference curves, M.P.I.C.s and the
ration group. This makes the model easier to represent in two dimensions and the
asymmetry is a virtue rather than a necessary evil in so far as rationing never covers
all goods in practice.

Especially significant, in view of the indiscriminate lumping of property income
