the interest rate affect consumption in opposite directions, even though they affect
property income in the same direction. Furthermore, property income may vary
(over moderate time periods) without producing any change in wealth or the interest
rate or, by our hypothesis, in consumption.

The adverse effect of an interest rate rise upon consumption may be greatly
augmented through its effect on wealth. Unless they are offset by equivalent changes
in the expected earnings of assets, interest rate changes produce opposite changes in
their market values. But induced changes in the earnings of assets depend upon the
responsiveness of investment to interest rate changes. Consequently, to the extent
that (expected) investment fails to respond to, say, monetary measures, consumption
responds that much more strongly. Our analysis therefore tends to reaffirm the effective-
ness of the rate of interest as a means of implementing economic policy.

The fiscal policy implications of our discussion are far from novel. lt indicates
the necessity of distinguishing fiscal measures that affect expectations (e.g., permanent
payroll taxes) from those which affect consumption only through the transfer of
wealth. In this connection, the inferior effectiveness of transfers not embodied in
permanent programs as compared with government purchases of goods and services
is apparent. Our analysis also serves as a reminder that transfer (tax) measures are
effective before payment is made or even accrued, the effect upon wealth, human
wealth, or the rate of interest beginning when adoption of the measure is first recognized
as likely. In short, the lack of evident response to the culmination of such measures
can often be ascribed to leads, rather than lags, and speed in their execution (e.g., in
tax collection) may not be very vital to their effectiveness.

We turn now to a more general discussion of the implication of our system of

total expenditure, at least if the curves are fitted with the assumption of independent
errors which we have used. The calculation of the differences, however, confirms the
impression to be gained from Fig. 3, namely that these are of a very small order, in
most cases below 1 per cent of total expenditure. Thus it would be very difficult if
not impossible to distinguish between the present system and one which included the
additional restraint of additivity, since the discrepancies are within the errors of the
estimates. Secondly, in our discussion we have not so far taken account of inferior
goods; that is, those possessing a negative income elasticity. If the good is inferior
over the whole range of income, it may be analysed with the use of equation (2), in

VII. CONCLUSIONS

We have seen that the existence of individual demand functions implies the
existence of an aggregate demand function only under rather restrictive conditions.
Even if the individual demand functions are identical, we have found it difficult to
make inferences from knowledge of them to knowledge of the aggregate demand
function, or conversely. If individual demand functions differ, these problems are
accentuated, and in particular it is easy to make false inferences about the shape of
individual demand functions from budget study data. Finally, we found that a study
of the aggregation problem could be very helpful in postulating the shape of demand
functions for indivisible commodities, and could, indeed, save us from serious practical
errors.

IV

Professor Arrow has posed a rather uninteresting problem. In particular we have
argued the following three propositions :

(1) Social choice procedures should not be chosen in ignorance of the particular
choice situations that are likely to confront the community in the near future.
All other choice situations are irrelevant. Each choice situation poses a unique
problem of compromise ; for each situation a different procedure may be appro-
priate. Some doubt was cast on the utility of formalising the conditions of
particular compromise choices, i.e. of constructing choice procedures.

(2) Social choice procedures should not be required to yield transitive order-
ings.

(3) Social orderings should not be necessarily based on individual orderings

in the situations being examined.! This approach, however, wishes to evaluate different
general policies or situations independently of judgments on the distribution of welfare
It does this by making statements which do not conflict with a wide range of such
final judgments. If the utility-possibility curve of one situation lies entirely outside
another so that everyone could be made better off for any initial distribution of welfare,
this analysis concludes that the first siiuation is potentially superior to the other.
If economists desire to have as little to do as possible with distribution judgments,
they should, it would seem, restrict themselves to this type of analysis. Of course, if the
potentially superior general policy change is carried out, the selection of the particular
welfare position to which the move should be made requires a distribution judgment.

The economist might enlarge somewhat the scope of his study from this approach
by considering only a range of possible welfare distributions. Many welfare positions
may be generally unacceptable for political reasons at the time a change is considered.
The relation of the situation utility-possibility curves in this range would be irrelevant.
Since a distribution judgment is finally required to make a particular change in welfare,
one might go still further and decide that the relation of the curves within the politically
feasible range is relevant only to the extent that no welfare position should be judged
to be the best under the circumstances, if it is possible to improve everyone's welfare
over that position. But the choice of a welfare position satisfying these conditions
must be left to the investigator. Of course, this amounts to the Bergson approach
except that social welfare functions, whose maximum welfare positions are within
the politically unacceptable range, are excluded. This would appear to be a more
realistic approach than that suggested by Little.

IV

In current discussions of economics, one seldom hears a kind word for welfare
economics. The disillusionment caused by the destruction of the original claims that
welfare economics could be based on objective economic criteria, independently of
judgments about interpersonal distributions of income, has led to general cynicism
towards the subject. Successive qualifications and retrenchments made in the field
seem to have left only an idle plaything—useful perhaps for learning certain general
equilibrium relationships but little else. Basically, many of the objections reflect the
sterility of static general equilibrium analysis, which has dominated economics for
years, as a concept for analysing the real economic world. Economists have much to
say which is useful concerning the allocation of resources, but in the real world the
problem is much more complex than the traditional approach can lead one to believe.
These differences between the model and reality and the importance of the non-
economic factors point up the insignificance of the contribution from the ''new
welfare " economics for reaching policy decisions. Until the dynamic aspects of con-
sumer behaviour and production theory can be handled better by economists, modern
welfare economics cannot be expected to make much of an analytical contribution
to policy-making. Furthermore, welfare economics can never be more than ''a
systematic way of introducing from outside of economics various ethical norms.''?
But this in itself is a worthwhile objective. For almost every economist recommends
policy, and, unless the value judgments underlying the recommendations are presented
in an orderly manner, we will continue to have those frustrating arguments which
appear to be about economic analysis but often turn out to be a matter of ethics.

The difference between this approach and Dr. Hansen's should be clearly noted.
It is more than a mere reversal of the order of the disinflationary measures suggested
by the latter. The first phase of the policy is not a measure to extinguish inflationary
excess demand—it is a move to re-establish the equilibrium relationship between
prices and wages. Only the second phase is genuinely disinflationary.

The foregoing discussion should not be construed as denying the possibility of the
existence of a labour shortage. This term is generally understood to mean that there
is not enough labour to produce an output which would fully satisfy the total demand.
The entrepreneurs may desire to employ additional workers even if that implies
increasing their wages because they expect that at least a part of the currently un-
satisfied demand will remain active at a higher price. The labour shortage in this
sense is caused by the existence of the excess demand for commodities, and so it is
bound to disappear as soon as the entrepreneurs realise that the excess demand for
commodities has itself disappeared. On the other hand, Dr. Hansen's approach implies
that the capitalists, in order to secure additional labour, may agree to pay higher
wages even if they are not allowed to raise prices. (The rise in prices mentioned by
Dr. Hansen is not caused by the marking-up designed to offset the wage concessions
but by the re-opening of the commodity gap due to the increase in demand resulting
from the rise in wages.)

It appears to the present writer that it is legitimate to assume that if wages are
controlled they are normally so fixed as to correspond, at least approximately, to the
marginal productivity of labour, and that wage increases necessary to establish and
maintain a healthy price-wage relationship may be allowed for in advance.? In these
circumstances the neglect of the factor gap is perfectly justified—the persistence
of labour shortage after the deflation of the demand for commodities is only possible
as a result of miscalculations and other frictional causes which the ordinary operation
of market forces may gradually eliminate.

The foregoing discussion of Dr. Hansen's models suggests that his denial of the
significance of the excess of ex-ante Investment over ex-ante Saving for the analysis
of inflation is valid only within the framework of his particular approach to this prob-
lem.? But as this essay has sought to show, the traditional approach remains superior
because the concepts it uses have, under the conditions of suppressed inflation, real
contents of great significance while the majority of Dr. Hansen's concepts are, under
these conditions, purely formal. The usefulness of the concept and analysis of the
Inflationary Gap lies in that it expresses the magnitude of the restriction of demand
which must be. enforced if the inflationary forces are not to generate the spiral of price
and cost increases. It follows that the problem cannot be analysed in terms of aggre-
gated private (erroneous) expectations, but must be dealt with in terms of global
magnitudes. Thus, the traditional approach provides a better explanation of the
nature of the phenomenon and a sounder theoretical basis for policy.

SIGNIFICANCE OF THE ANALYSIS

We have applied here the simple techniques of static equilibrium analysis to a
fairly complicated problem. The complications are due partly to special peculiarities
of the particular type of firm under study, and partly to the large number of variables
introduced. As a result the model bears some resemblance to firms of this kind in the
real world, and has been found by the writer to be a useful tool in studying newspaper
economics. The lesson might be that provided we are prepared to introduce sufficient
variables and assume reasonably realistic relationships between them, the models of
partial equilibrium can be as useful as those of macro-economics.

The features of our model which have complicated the analysis may be summarised
as follows :

I. Our firm produces (at first) two products, the quantities supplied of one of
these determining the quality of the other. At the end a third product is introduced.

2. On the non-advertising side, quality rather than price has been assumed to be
variable. This assumption is justified purely because newspaper managements are in
practice constantly varying the quality of their products, while regarding prices as far
less variable. The assumption of constant quality and variable price would have
produced a far more simple and orthodox picture.

3. On the advertising side we have assumed price and quality, as well as quantity,
variable.

lose. Here, for once, it is wise to accept an argument analogous to Descarte's argument
for belief in God. We should base our decisions on probable knowledge, for if that
fails to save us we have lost nothing which could be reliably saved by any other method ;
but if it succeeds we will have acted wisely. In the long run of such action—if there
is a long run—we will have maximised our chances of success, and indeed we will
maximise our prospects for a long run itself.

Finally, to. test one lingering doubt on the matter of the relevance of probability
to crucial choices (even in the death case), imagine how one's responses might be
affected if one supposed the values for the probability were heavily on the side of
failure (or death) for some particular choice. How long could one remain indifferent
to such probable knowledge ?

If we accept the preceding analysis we will apply probable knowledge to single
events. We may assign the probability of the class of events to a single event by
"' positing " that event with a weight equal to the class probability. Then, if we act on
the basis of the posit, we will maximise our chance of success in the long run of all
such decisions.!

II4 THE REVIEW OF ECONOMIC STUDIES

Although the analysis of risk does not provide us with a general explanation of
the rate of investment, it does throw some interesting sidelights on the problems of
the firm. As we have seen, the firm facing a small possibility of large losses would have
more difficulty in obtaining loans than the firm facing a large possibility of small
losses. Other things being equal, the latter would have more chance of expanding
than the former. The fact that risk declines with size also shows that even under
constant returns to scale, the entrepreneur who starts with a large capital has a better
chance of success than the small entrepreneur—and that even under the most stringent
assumptions of perfect competition.

Kalecki's analysis leaves another puzzle : if constant returns to scale prevail,
and if risk remains constant regardless of the size of the firm, while the entrepreneur
prefers, other things being equal, not to commit all of his capital in one enterprise,
why is it that firms grow, and what determines their minimum size ? It appears that

In the case of large, widely held corporations, the analysis presented in Fig. 1
does not apply, as the individual's holdings of the stock of a large enterprise is usually
insignificant compared with the total outstanding stock, and forms a small fraction of

are limited mainly because the state of the market puts a limit on potential expansion.

Kalecki postulated the '' Principle of Increasing Risk '"' in order to give a general
explanation of the limit of investment per unit time, both in the individual firm, and

It is difficult to find examples of totally uncorrelated risks : the drilling of wildcat
oil wells is possibly the best one. The risk of total failure in a one-well wildcatting
enterprise is very high. The risk of total failure of a large oil concern is very low,
though the risk of any one well being dry is the same for a large and for a small concern.

The assumption of total lack of correlation between the risks attached to individual
units of investment made by the same enterprise is clearly unrealistic, but it is equally
unrealistic to assume that the risks are perfectly correlated, which is the condition of
constant risk to size.! Available evidence shows that small enterprises are more risky
than large ones : their discontinuance rate is higher, the variation of profits over the
cycle is greater, and, at any given time, the range of profitability is higher. The overall
profitability of large and small enterprises over the whole cycle seems roughly equal.?
It is, therefore, reasonable to assume that risk declines with size and that riskless
profit remains the same. The declining risk at constant returns to scale is shown in
Fig. 4 by the dotted lines. Lines AG, B'E' and F'Q' replace now the lines 44", BE and
FQ respectively.

If " increasing risk " could be used as a universal explanation of limitation of
expansion per unit time, we could expect higher loan-to-asset ratios in the case of
large than in the case of small enterprises, which would permit larger enterprises to
expand faster than smaller ones. Facts do not support this hypothesis. Although
large enterprises contract their loans at much lower cost than small firms do (which
is in keeping with the theory, for risk is less in large enterprises) :

The equity capital of the small firms provided only about r/2 of their total
assets, compared with about 2/3 or 3/4 of the assets of the large corporations.—
[Osborn (xo).]

Obviously, the principle of increasing risk does not explain the difference between
the financial structure of large and small corporations. Moreover, if increasing risk
did provide an explanation for the limit of expansion per unit time of small corpora-
tions, it clearly does not do so in case of large corporations where the loan-to-asset
ratio is lower, and the weighted risk is smaller.

To solve our dilemma we have to fall back on explanations based on considera-
tions of market imperfections and monopoly elements. Small firms do not have a
ready access to the equity market, and the potential lenders are in a strong monopoly
position, as shown by Nicholson (9) and others. A large proportion of small firms'
loans are contracted on a short-term basis, an expensive source of capital, because of
the difficulty of floating long-term obligations. Large firms, on the other hand, are
in a strong position on the finance market ; there is no evidence that large firms
would expand faster if more finance were available, as the expansion rate is very
largely regulated by considerations of potential demand. Another factor also has to
be taken into account: small firms are mostly closely held corporations, and the
small entrepreneur might put a high financial value on ownership and control. The
issue of equity shares might involve the loss of control. Thus the small entrepreneur
might be more willing to contract loans than to issue equity shares. In large enter-
prises ownership is usually divorced from control, and, therefore, the deterrent against
the issue of equity shares does not exist.

The rate of economic expansion is limited, according to Kalecki, by the increase
of the lender's risk and of the entrepreneur's risk with the increase of expansion of
the firm per unit time. In this paper it will be shown that the '' principle of increasing
risk " does not provide a sufficient explanation of the limit of the rate of investment
in the general case, for although the entrepreneur's risk and the lender's risk increase
with the size of the loan, given an arbitrary amount of the entrepreneur's own capital,
the risk of the enterprise as a whole declines with increasing size. A determinate
solution arises only under special assumptions, but the investigation of the "risk
function "' is fruitful in that it sheds light on the differences in financial structure and
in the rate of growth of undertakings operating under different risk conditions.

I

Under the assumptions of perfect competition the size of the individual firm and
the rate of expansion of the firm are indeterminate. The Theory of Monopolistic
Competition attempts to explain how investment per unit time is determined, but the
explanation is clearly inadequate :

Imperfect competition . . . operates to limit the portion of & (the available
capital) invested in any particular field, but not the limit to the total amount of &.
On the other hand, imperfect competition cannot account for the fact that in a
given industry large and, small enterprises are started. [Kalecki (6, p. 98).]

It seems dangerous to assume that monopolistic competition prevails in all fields
of economic activity without exception, and yet investment per unit time is clearly

There are two reasons for the increase of marginal risk with the amount
invested. The first is the fact that the greater the investment of an entrepreneur
the more is his wealth position endangered in the event of unsuccessful business.
The second reason is the danger of ''illiquidity " . . . the amount invested &
must be considered as a fully illiquid asset in case of a sudden need for '' capital."
In that situation the entrepreneur who has invested in equipment his reserves
and taken '' too much credit " is obliged to borrow at a rate of interest which is
higher than the market one. . . . If, however, the entrepreneur is not cautious
in his investment activity it is the creditor who imposes on his calculations the
burden of increasing risk charging the successive portions of credit above a certain
amount with rising rate of interest. [Kalecki (5, p. 442).]

Investment is thus determined by the intersection of the marginal efficiency of
capital curve with the increasing risk curve. The smaller the initial capital of the
entrepreneur, the greater is the entrepreneur's risk at any given level of investment.

smaller the maximum absolute expansion per unit time. The maximum aggregate
investment per unit time can be readily obtained by summing up the individual

Take, finally, the distinction between '' cost " inflation and '' demand "' inflation.
Demand inflation may arise quite independently of any change in costs, as when
government expenditure, investment, or export prices suddenly increase. In a free
economy this increase of demand leads to rising prices and so to rising costs and
incomes ; ie. it sets off inflation. In a controlled economy it is theoretically possible
that there will be no such repercussions upon prices, and hence no secondary effects
upon incomes, because controls succeed in stifling the initial increase in demand.
But, as has already been noted, controls can be effective only if they do not pull too
strongly against market forces, which are now strengthened by the increase of demand.

Cost inflation occurs in its purest form in a controlled economy. In this case an
autonomous rise in costs, e.g. a rise in the real wage rate or in prices of imported
materials, can set off inflation only if there is already excess demand to absorb this
rise of costs into prices, or if the rise in costs itself swells aggregate demand. This
last possibility depends upon business expectations and credit policy, and, more
directly, upon whether the rise in costs leads to an immediate rise in incomes. Such
a rise occurs if there is an increase in real wages, but it does not occur if the rise in
costs is caused by an increase in import prices. It appears, therefore, that directly or
indirectly demand is the fundamental factor in all inflationary processes, and that
measures to restrain or reduce aggregate demand are fundamental for the control of
inflation.!

6. This last section will discuss briefly the significance of the integrability con-
dition in utility theory. Georgescu-Roegen, in an important paper published in 1936,!
demonstrated that the possibility that indifference elements could be integrated into
curves or surfaces did not, of itself, guarantee that those curves and surfaces were
indifference curves and surfaces.? The condition that the two types of surface, integral
surface and indifference surface, should coincide is that indifference should be a
transitive relation. If transitivity is assumed, however, Georgescu-Roegen showed
that that condition alone is sufficient for the indifference elements to be integrable.

the transitivity condition is not fulfilled, then the integral surfaces are not necessarily
indifference surfaces ; and if the transitivity condition is satisfied, then the integra-
bility conditions are redundant. It is the transitivity condition alone that is im-

ortant.?

Houthakker theorem establishes the transitivity of revealed equivalence. Once this
is established, the integrability of the '' equivalence " elements follows almost as a
by-product of the theorem. If it were demonstrated only that the ''equivalence "
elements were integrable, without at the same time demonstrating that the '' equiva-
lence " is transitive, then the existence of a consistent total utility function would
not be proved. Put in another way, the integrability conditions are a necessary but
not a sufficient condition for the existence of a total utility function ; while the
transitivity condition (the other conditions for equivalence being satisfied) is both
necessary and sufficient.

XI. SUMMARY

A survey of the literature reveals that there has been a great deal of confusion
in the matter of external economies and the downward-sloping supply curve, and that
nowhere have the conditions of the interrelationships been worked out in detail.
This paper has attempted to work out these interrelationships, and its main points
may be summarised as follows :-

(i) When there is a circular interdependence among the supply curves of the
firms in an industry, it is impossible to obtain the industry supply curve by the process
of simple summation. A unique industry supply curve may be obtained, however,
by the solution of a set of simultaneous equations, either directly or by successive
approximations.

(2) When such circular interdependence exists, the industry supply curve may
be either more or less steep than the supply curve derived by blowing up the supply
curve of the typical firm—depending upon whether there exist external diseconomies
or external economies.

) The necessary condition for the industry supply curve to be actually forward-
falling is that there be present external economies of such magnitude that any increase
in industry output sets in motion forces which make all firms together wish to increase
their output more than the original increase.

(4) This forward-falling supply curve is not a true supply curve in the sense of
tracing out the quantities that will be supplied with shifts in the price offered to the
industry ; itisrather the locus of price ànd quantity traced out by shifts in a sufficiently
steep demand curve. —

(5) The question of stability of equilibrium between demand and forward-falling
supply was investigated, leading to the familiar condition that the demand curve
must cut the supply curve from above. If, however, the demand curve cuts it too
steeply, the possibility exists that an unstable cobweb might be generated.

We have so far discussed cases in which the quality of a commodity was described
by one variable, its unit price under some basic price system. This approach clearly
has severe limitations, most of which we have already indicated. AÀ much greater
flexibility can be attained by introducing more variables to specify a variety of an
item of consumption. If we are speaking of an overcoat we may, e.g., give quantitative
expressions for its size, weight, colour, warmth, etc. The consumer will then be sup-
posed to have preferences for various combinations of these characteristics, rather
than for overcoats which are only described by their price. On the other hand, the
price of the coat will also depend on these characteristics, since they are produced by
different factor inputs (in the widest sense). Here we again meet a situation where
the supply side cannot be ignored ; in the single-variable case this was only possible
because supply problems were implicitly assumed to be solved in the form of a price
schedule which could only shift or tilt.

An adequate discussion of the multi-quality case will therefore have to await
further reconnaissance, in the area between consumption theory and the theory of the
firm. Some of the methods used in the present paper can easily be extended to these
problems.

Finally, we should remark that the multi-variable specification as just outlined
represents a fundamental change in the approach to consumption theory, since attention
is paid to the reasons why consumers want certain goods. This may also prove interest-
ing for studies of the demand for newly invented goods. A theory of this kind would
consequently be of a rather different and much less orthodox nature from the one

analysis differs but little from ordinary consumption theory ; hence, while one some-
times gets different and slightly more general results in "' interdependent " as com-
pared with '" independent " preference analysis, it is only in this very limited and

detract from their interest or explanatory usefulness.

As with an increase in the quantity of money, the effect on the rate of interest
of an increase in the velocity of circulation depends on the subsidiary assumptions
made. A decrease in the desire to hold idle balances must, if nothing else is assumed
to change, have the effect of lowering the rate of interest to the point at which the
increased transactions balances required to circulate the increased income generated
by the increased investment produced by the lower rate of interest, plus the increased
liquid balances held as a result of the lower interest rate, together become equal to the
(unchanged) stock of money. Only if there is full employment before the change
occurs will the rate of interest ultimately be the same as it was before. If, on the
other hand, it is assumed that the reduced desire to hold idle balances is accompanied
by an increased desire to invest (or consume), which is what is involved when an
entrepreneur "' activises "" an idle balance by purchasing commodities or hiring labour,
then the increase in velocity will raise the rate of interest by raising income and draining
money out of idle balances into transactions balances. But the rise in the rate of
interest must be attributed to the decision to increase investment, not to the decision
to hold a smaller idle balance.

Put another way, a decision to reduce idle balances may be eher a decision to
hold another kind of asset instead (i.e. to hold securities) or a decision to reduce one's
assets in order to increase current expenditure. In the former case the rate of interest
is lowered, in the latter case it is raised. In both cases the conclusion will only follow
if the decision is taken as the result of a lasting change in attitude.

It is true, as Professor Robertson points out, that the Keynesian theory does
throw the emphasis on substitution between money and securities. But this does not
prevent analysis in Keynesian terms of decisions to reduce idle balances in order to
purchase goods : the decision needs merely to be separated into its two parts, and the
same conclusion about the effect on the rate of interest will follow.

Whether Professor Robertson is right or wrong in his contention that Keynes

and Professor Robertson thinking more of the history of industrial fluctuations; part
of it is a difference of opinion over the importance of bank-financed investment as an
independent variable. The latter difference is a question of fact, to which the answer
may be different for difference historical periods.

VIL. THE THREE-FOLD MARGIN!

Professor Robertson is quite right in arguing that the proposition that the rate
of interest governs the desire to hold idle money is not inconsistent with the
proposition that the rate of interest may also govern saving.

If saving does depend in some way on the rate of interest as well as on the level
of income, however, this dependence can very easily be introduced into the Keynesian
theory. It merely means that instead of one propensity to consume (or to save) there
will be one for each rate of interest: and the relation between saving and interest
will have an influence on the determination of the equilibrium levels of income and the
rate of interest. When income is in equilibrium, the rate of interest will not only
equate the demand for money at that level of income with the existing stock of money,
but will also equate the rate of investment with the saving that the community is
willing to do from that income at that rate of interest. Nor does it matter, within the
limits stated by Professor Robertson, whether saving is assumed to rise or fall as the
rate of interest rises.

Keynes is describing a logical system in which it is assumed that the propensity to

income will only be higher if the level of investment is higher ; on the second assump-
tion, investment will only be higher if the rate of interest is lower. Consequently a
higher level of income is necessarily associated with a lower rate of interest. Professor
Robertson is referring to a historical situation in which the quantity of money is
rigid or sticky and income is rising as a result of a rise in the marginal efficiency of
capital or the propensity to consume. On these assumptions, the Keynesian theory
would also show rising output and prices associated with rising rates of interest. The
difference of assumptions is the key to the solution of this particular disagreement ;
the same difference of assumptions reappears in the controversy over the relation
between the quantity of money and the rate of interest (fra, section IX).

V. THE CONFUSED STATEMENT FROM THE GENERAL THEORY, p. 165!

Professor Robertson is entirely justified in denouncing Keynes' statement that
* the schedule of the marginal efficiency of capital may be said to govern the terms
on which loanable funds are demanded for the purpose of new investment; whilst
the rate of interest governs the terms on which funds are being currently supplied."'

The sentence seems to assume that the rate of interest is fixed by the quantity
of money in conjunction with liquidity preference, independently of the level of invest-
ment ; in fact, the rate of interest in the Keynesian theory depends on the quantity
of money in conjunction with boh liquidity preference and the level of income, and
the latter in turn depends on the level of investment as determined by the marginal
efficiency of capital and the rate of interest. It is, therefore, not possible to analyse
the determination of investment in the Keynesian theory in the way implied by the
sentence, since the rate of interest is not determined independently of the level of
investment. Most of Keynes' chapter 14 is rather confusing for this sort of reason ;
the subject is more easily understood with the help of the Hicksian IS-LM diagram.

VI. THE ALLEGED INCONSISTENCY IN THE SCHEME OF THE GENERAL
THEORY?

The inconsistency in the scheme of the General Theory consists, according to
Professor Robertson, in the fact that in the theory the banks can only operate by
increasing "idle money " ; but that on certain pages Keynes assumes that, even if
* jdle money "' is zero, total money can be increased and the rate of interest pushed
down. This alleged inconsistency turns out on inspection to be groundless. If the
demand for idle money is nil, then one of the characteristics of all positions of ultimate
equilibrium is that the stock of idle money will be nil; but, even if the banks are
restricted to creating idle money (e.g. by purchasing securities), this does not mean
that they are powerless to increase the quantity of money, as Professor Robertson's
argument would imply. The effect of such purchases of securities would be initially
to create idle money, whose holders would immediately seek to reinvest in securities ;
the result would be to drive up the prices of securities, and drive down the rate of
interest to the point at which the increased investment induced by the lower interest

CONCLUSION

The foregoing analysis should suggest that price discrimination and multiple-
product production are not exceptions to general practice, but are rather the essence
of customary action. The distinction between a producer selling a single product at
different prices and one selling different products in varying markets at differing
percentages of profit is a distinction of degree only. What a firm has to sell is not a
product, but rather its capacity to produce. In so far as firms are motivated by the
marginal principle, there is a tendency to push production towards the point where
marginal cost is equal to demand price for the least profitable unit produced. In this
manner "' capacity " operation is achieved. The limits to the process are institutional
rather than theoretical. Under conditions of monopolistic competition this probably
results in a situation where only normal profits are obtained. Whatever the amount
of profit, it is obtained only by constant manipulation of the price and product line.
The theory of price discrimination must be viewed as the heart of price-cost theory
rather than a peripheral case. The firm that does not discriminate in its pricing policy,
or differentiate in its product line, or invade new markets, dies in the competitive
struggle—and '' business management does not commit suicide."

For the sake of completeness, certain of the well-known deficiencies of such a
rudimentary income model will be enumerated. In the first place, the model shares
with other forms of elementary economic analysis the inaccuracies imposed by a desire

price flexibility—structural and cyclical—fail consideration. The absence of markets
compels us to neglect the role of imperfection in determining the level of employment.

account is given of the relationship between long and short term rates. Nor is it acknow-
ledged that liquidity preference actually pertains not only to the relationship between
cash and non-cash assets, but to the relationship among all kinds of assets of varying

Despite these and other deficiencies, the model may be useful as a basis for further
refinement and criticism of the Keynesian system.

I.

The rudiments of the Keynesian system as applied to a closed economy may be
presented to beginning students by means of a simple, linear model consisting of six
variables, two parameters, and six equations. The variables are Y, C, 7, R, M, and M;.
Y is the aggregate flow in income during a specific period. C represents aggregate
expenditures by the private sector of the community on consumer goods and services.
I represents net expenditures by the private sector of the community on investment
goods. R, the rate of interest, symbolises the structure of interest rates rather than
" the " rate of interest.? M, stands for that portion of the money supply held for the
purpose of satisfying the transactions and precautionary motives. M, represents
money held as an asset—that is, to satisfy the speculative motive.

It is possible for bull carry-over to exceed bear! carry-over, since money may be

It is also possible for bear carry-over to exceed bull carry-over since money may
be borrowed in return for payment of contango (or for receipt of backwardation), i.e.
shares may be given on, not only by bulls, but also directly by others (mainly jobbers)
who are long of shares.? They will presumably be prepared to do this, not only if there
is a backwardation, but also if contango rate is somewhat below the rate (per fort-
nightly account period) on loans to the Stock Exchange. It follows that an excess of
bear carry-over against bull carry-over does not necessarily involve a backwardation
and thus that the existence of a contango does ^oi necessarily mean an excess of bull
carry-over. On the other hand, a backwardation does necessarily mean an excess of
bear carry-over and probably also an excess of bears over al] bulls, since most bulls
will find it profitable to carry-over when there is a backwardation.

Bear carry-over can only exceed bull carry-over by a limited amount equal to
the maximum number of shares that those with shares will give on, while bull carry-
over can exceed bear carry-over to a very great extent since money can be attracted
into the market from outside. Consequently, while there is the fairly low and definite
upper limit to contango mentioned above, there is no such limit to backwardation
which may rise to extreme heights if the bears cannot cover themselves easily by
reversing their transactions. A high backwardation will be accompanied by a rise in
share prices at the end of the period, for the covering purchases by bears will send up
prices which they had themselves depressed earlier by their sales.

I.

Nearly all writers on interest theory, whether they favour a stock approach or a
flow approach, seem now to be agreed that the demand for securities of speculators
must be included in any analysis of the formation of interest rates. There is perhaps
a smaller degree of agreement as to whether analysis in terms of the demand and
supply of money is permissible. This latter problem boils down to the question of what
assumptions are made. If bonds and money are the only assets held by wealth-owners
and if the aggregate demand for both goods and factor services equals their aggregate
supply, then any excess demand for money must reflect an equal and opposite excess
supply of bonds. In such circumstances, we can say indifferently that the bond-rate
of interest is determined by the demand and supply of money or by the demand
and supply of bonds. An analysis restricted by such assumptions can, however, only
be a first approximation. Where we wish to consider, say, shares and short-loans as
well as bonds and money, discussion of the price-formation of any of the first three
is best carried out in terms of the demand and supply of the asset in question.

No analysis of speculative demand can be satisfactory unless the existence of a
money-market is assumed. Only if short-loans to the Stock Exchange exist can the
activities of bull speculators be adequately included, since if there is no short borrowing
a speculator's money balance can only be positive and never negative, thus making
the analysis asymmetrical. Granted this, the case is made for analysing the price of any
security in terms of its demand and supply.

This paper is concerned with only one type of demand, speculative demand.
Firstly, an attempt is made to restate the main determinants of the position and shape
of the stock speculative demand curve for shares which, as this is a second approxima-
tion only, are assumed to be homogeneous. Secondly, having assumed carry-over
facilities to exist for share transactions, an analysis is given of the determination of
the contango (or backwardation) rate.!

speculator. As Dr. Wilson? has pointed out, Keynes' " speculators who are trying to
beat the gun are a very different type from Mr. Kaldor's careful arithmeticians with
their eyes fixed on the relationship between expected short-term rates and the yield
on high-grade bonds." Here we shall define a speculator as a person or institution
whose security transactions are made largely in order to secure short-run capital gains.
This is nearer to the Keynesian type than to Mr. Kaldor's.

THOMAS JOPLIN AND THE THEORY OF INTEREST 163

use to which the Classical concept of surplus and the labour theory of value could be
put. To demonstrate that interest was a reward for the act of saving, rather than an
income in the nature of a surplus, it was necessary, first, to discover some aspect of
the saving process which could plausibly be presented as involving a real cost or
sacrifice on the part of the saver, and, second, to posit a direct functional relationship
between the volume of saving and the rate of interest. It is sometimes assumed by
historians that the idea of a functional connection between the supply of capital and
its return (involving the recognition of a real cost lying behind accumulation) was a
necessary element in the Ricardian theory of equilibrium.! This does not appear to me
to have been the case : the idea was not, in fact, developed until it was found desirable
to stress the existence of such a cost.

The tendency to think of saving as a function of the rate of interest, then, may at
least in its origin have been associated with the desire to show, first, that the economic
system was fundamentally stable, and, second, that it was not founded on the exploita-
tion of the labourer. But one other factor of some importance intensified the tendency,
and was largely responsible for the failure of orthodox economics to exorcise it before
1936. Professor Myint has recently drawn attention to the significant difference
between the economic problem with which the Classical economists were concerned,
and that with which we are mainly concerned to-day.? The Classical economists were
chiefly interested in the problem of zncreasing the wealth of the nation—in securing
abundance. Modern economists, on the other hand (at least since the 1870's), have
become interested primarily in the problem of allocating a. given pool of resources as
*' efficiently " as possible—in making the best of scarcity.? Now, for obvious reasons,
the idea that saving should be regarded as a function of the rate of interest has usually
been associated with theories which think in terms of the amount saved out of a given
income. The idea that saving should be regarded as a function of income, on the
other hand, has usually been stressed by economists who were mainly interested in the
causes of variations in income. The transfer of attention from the Classical to the
modern economic problem, then, meant that the Classical concept of saving as a
function of income, upon which Joplin built his analysis in the Owilines, began to
appear, not only as inferior to its successor from an apologetic point of view, but also
as actually irrelevant.

power is the sole determinant of property income generated from the capitalist process,
ie. that capitalist income and its various categories were historically-derived by-
products of the application of social power in a specific institutional setting. This may
be considered the limiting case of a model with a labour market wholly insensitive to
market forces. At the other extreme may be postulated a Walrasian model of a purely
competitive labour and resource market which would yield a set of factoral prices and
incomes untouched by the influence of social power. One could start with the Marxian
version and re-work by including elements from the Walrasian version ; or contrari-
wise, more insight might be achieved by commencing with the Walrasian version as
the most general case subsequently modified by intrusion of the specific Marxian
labour market with its distortionary effects, its open-ended areas, and the element of
class struggle which it provides.

The Marxian analysis of the social power patterning of the working process within
capitalist enterprise and of the productive and distributive process of the capitalist
economy comprises one of the many focal centres of interest for modern theory in the
Marxian corpus. Though this patterning was elucidated in the setting of the Mehrwert
approach there is no logical connection between the two. Whether income be rigidly
dichotomised or differentiated into many fluid groupings would be relatively indifferent
to the question of the social power patterning of workshop behaviour in all its dimen-
sions and of the functioning of the labour market generally.

Thus the continued adequacy for purposes of present-day social and economic
theory of the Marxian Mehrwert approach and concept of pure capitalism remains a
highly dubious one. Its primary field of application—that of the elucidation of exposure,
both of exploitation and of the ideological mystification involved in a vulgar bourgeois
ideology—has to a very great extent been outmoded by the transformation in social
ideology and popular mentality on the one hand and by the far-reaching permeation
on the other hand of anti-bourgeois outlook into the thought-categories of current
social science. The very subject matter of analysis has been thoroughly transformed in
many crucial aspects involving the formation of new institutional Gestalt patterns.
To be sure the Marxian organon retains its full measure of logical validity and analytical
coherence vis-à-vis its subject matter and with given purposes in view. "We found the
organon to be only slightly dependent upon the labour value theorem whose presence
or modification would not occasion significant logical disturbances and constituted a
source of not unfruitful insight.

Yet our paper has not suggested that the Marxian organon can simply be neglected.
If our theory had developed in keeping with the development of its materials, the
Marxian organon would have been fully assimilated into a body of workable theory
and knowledge differentiated into more complex and revealing patterns than either its
precursors or raw materials. Only a person with a live sense of humour would suggest
that this has been the case. We have innumerable beginnings but few completions ;
we have a vastly enriched body of materials but more discordance; we have a pro-
liferation of departmental enquiries with impoverished integration as social study with
a socio-economic core. So long as this is the case both the Marxian Mehrwert concept
and analysis of capitalism can be neglected only at one's peril. From Marx, too, one
can derive not only an elucidation of a phase of capitalist development, but an analytic
method rich with fruitful possibilities: the art of abstraction to isolate essential
reality, deliberate integration of psychological-social-economic foci of interest into
unified logical structures, the disclosure of a developing complexus of activity.

What Mr. Ichimura has shown is that there is more to it than that. This looseness
or unfirmness only holds with respect to the original relation between changes in
marginal valuations—which is a matter, in terms of the distinctions made in the
preceding paragraph of this note, of the movement from situation 7 to situation I7;
Complementarity and competitiveness are not a matter of that movement; they are
concerned with the movement from situation /7 to situation 777. Here it is much
more reasonable to expect that we shall find the firmness we seek. We are digging
down nearer to the level at which we have to say : '' If, for whatever reason, I want
more 4A, I shall want more B too." But we can never quite get to that level, for it is
possible that the reason for which I want more A, may be such that it carries with it
a diminished demand for B. That special case cannot be ruled out.

It is not surprising that variations in prices, being general, unbiassed sorts of
things, not tied up with particular reasons, should dig down as near to this level as
we are likely to get. That is, I think, the fundamental meaning behind Mr. Ichimura's
theorem.

The careful reader will have noticed that the movement from II to III always
relates to the system of wants which exists affer the change in wants has taken place,
and that therefore it is not the same system which exists after one initial change
(J to II) as would exist after an initial change which had been different. Thus it is
not inevitable that complementarity of X and Y with respect to one parameter should
imply complementarity with respect to another. Certainly there is a lack of firmness
from this cause; but if the change in wants is not too great, it seems fair to say that
this difficulty is comparable with the difficulty which persists in the case of price-
changes with given wants (when there is a movement from one part of a given indiffer-
ence-map to another). We can therefore accept the conclusion that Ichimura-related-
ness and indifference-relatedness are identical in more than the formal sense; they
do both represent something which we can expect to use as a fairly firm classification

A NOTE ON MR. MEADE'S THEORY OF COMPETITIVE SPECULATION 189

In the presence of organised commodity speculation utilising a futures market, a
specialisation of function occurs in which the purely speculative functions of price-
appraisal and of risk-taking are divorced from the physical holding of stocks. The
speculator deals in contracts for future delivery and, in the pure case, never handles
the actual commodity ; he carries no physical stocks which might produce a con-
venience yield, nor does the nature of his business permit gaining a convenience yield
if he did hold stocks ; he has no costs of holding except commissions for executing the
futures contracts, and interest on the required ' margin " to guarantee his financial
responsibility, and these costs do not '' increase "' as is necessary for emergence of a
'"' speculators' surplus." The physical holding of stocks, in this situation, is left to
hedgers, and it is the hedgers who benefit from the '' surplus " that Mr. Meade finds
accruing in the presence of speculative holding.

Apart from this divorcement of functions, and consequent separation of the
recipients of speculative profit (or loss) from the recipients of holders' surplus,
speculation through a futures market may produce the same effects as speculation
that involves physical holding of the commodity by the speculator. If the effects are
different, it is because in the presence of a futures market the pure speculation is to a
considerable extent done by different people, and because the holders of physical
stocks act under the guidance of a rather accurately known prospective return for
holding, instead of having to be guided only by their appraisals of prospective price
change.1

Apart from the need for this supplementary observation, I find Mr. Meade's
analysis and conclusions penetrating and sound in theory, and highly pertinent to the
real world. As applied to organised commodity speculation, the assumptions conform
well with reality except as regards their neglect of the separation that then occurs
between speculation and the physical holding of stocks; and the conclusions are
readily modified to conform to that situation.

It is interesting to observe in passing that statistical studies indicate that in
markets where futures trading has been prominent, the general conditions of perfect
competitive speculation have been closely approximated. As regards wheat in the
United States, which historically has been the great holder of the excess stocks in
times of world wheat surplus,? the tendency seems to have been slightly on the side
of somewhat excessive willingness to hold in times of surplus.? This suggests a slight
degree of '' excessive " speculation in Mr. Meade's sense, though not necessarily exces-
sive speculation in the popular sense in which excessive speculation is associated with
unwarranted price fluctuations over short periods.*

III.

We have seen that Mr. Henderson cannot legitimately give the job of end-selection
to the Cabinet (or to any other group) without exploring the problem of who should
choose the ends for society. If we operate within the framework of a '' mass demo-
cracy," Mr. Henderson has indirectly placed his finger on one requirement which must
be fulfilled by the end-selecting agent. The democratic process can be pictured as one
in which the voters of the community choose between alternatives which are
presented to them, but cannot themselves set up these alternatives.? For obvious
sociological reasons, the agent who presents the alternatives must be an individual or
small group. In addition, the voters must be supplied with the information on which
to judge between alternatives. This function must also be performed for the electorate
rather than by it. Even though the Cabinet is a small group there is no reason to
suppose that any single group will present all the alternatives and all the information
needed. The democratic process implies not one but a series of such groups.

Unfortunately, there is nothing in this process which insures that the choices
made by the voters will form themselves into a usable ranking of alternatives for the
community (community preference system). This becomes clear when we consider

non- or irrational preference systems ; (2) the original set of alternatives on which
the vote was cast may have been incomplete ; (3) as Professor Arrow has pointed out,
the community preference system need not be "rational" even if the preference
system of each voter is rational? ; and finally, (4) the voting process is discontinuous

I.

In his short note, '' The Economist and the State," Mr. I. M. D. Little objects
strenuously to some remarks made by Mr. A. M. Henderson in a recent issue of this
Review. Mr. Henderson put forward the notion that the Cabinet is the proper agency
to translate '' the national interest "' into a series of specific goals. Further, he implied
that as economists we must wait for the Cabinet's interpretation, accept it, and then
proceed with the construction of our deductive systems.

To all this Mr. Little protests. After stating that the role of the economist is (hope-
fully) broader and less servile than Mr. Henderson implied, Mr. Little goes on to argue
that the value premises used by the welfare economist can originate in a great many
places: in the Cabinet, Parliament, the local pub, or in the mind of the individual
performing the deductions. For this reason he feels that Mr. Henderson was wrong
in restricting the economist to those value premises enunciated by the Cabinet.

It is my contention that Mr. Little was right in objecting to the Henderson
position—but for inappropriate reasons. If I have read the arguments of these two
men correctly, there is no necessary antagonism between their positions. Mr.
Henderson probably accepts the idea that '' value conclusions can only be deduced
from value premises." Further, he undoubtedly realises that these premises can arise
from any of a wide variety of sources. The problem, however, is not where they could
arise but where they should arise.

To reach the conclusion that the Cabinet should select the detailed ends toward
which the whole society ought to move, Mr. Henderson must have had some set of
postulates about the political system in the back of his mind. But Mr. Henderson has
shrouded in secrecy the postulational system from which he deduced his conclusion
about the Cabinet. Both Mr. Little and I are inclined to disagree with Mr. Henderson's
choice of the Cabinet as the end-selecting agency, but until he is more specific about
the reasons for his choice, it is impossible for me to state with any certainty the nature
of my objections. They could either be with his postulates, his deductions, or with
both.

II.

Whether or not Mr. Henderson had stated explicitly his assumptions concerning
the political system, it seems to me that one may still object to the narrow role assigned
the economist. Let us suppose that initial ends (postulates) have been given to the
economist (by himself or others) and that he has accepted the task of performing
deductions. This is the conventional picture of the economist's role and is, therefore,
suitable for analysis. Notice that in his generally accepted capacity of deducer, the
economist is permitted at most to restate the ends and then only in a manner which
will not influence the choice of the agent who does the selecting. But what if the ends
turn out on examination to be inconsistent ? Surely the economist has a right to
mention these inconsistencies. Presumably, the economist can also tell the selecting

they are long deferred, affect the capital value very little, but which for the same
reason are weighted so heavily in the average that they make the average period of
the marginal stream negative, then these same deferred inputs will exercise a very
strong influence on the difference between the capital values of this stream at different
rates of interest. This influence will make it impossible for a marginal stream with a
negative average period to be unprofitable at one rate of interest and to become
profitable with a slightly lower rate. But unless a stream does this it is not fitted to
be a marginal stream in the sense outlined above.

Potential surprise is measured to both sides (south and north) of the east-west
line in the base-plane. It increases with movements away from the east-west line in
either direction, up to a limit corresponding to absolute disbelief.

The intensity of the stimulus to the individual considering the possible course of
action imparted by his imagining any particular outcome in conjunction with any
particular degree of potential surprise is measured in the vertical direction. The
base-plane is taken to represent the degree of stimulus corresponding to a neutral
outcome, so that points corresponding to greater stimuli lie above it, and those corres-
ponding to lesser stimuli lie below it. The $-surface, which is the locus of all these
points, consequently intersects the base-plane along a curve which passes through the
point corresponding to a neutral outcome with zero potential surprise, i.e. the inter-
section of the east-west and north-south axes.

The shape of the $-surface itself is such that any horizontal cross-section of it
(e.g. by the base-plane) resembles an elongated S or the summation sign of the integral
calculus, and intersects the east-west axis from the south-west direction at something
less than a right-angle. The reasons for these characteristics are as follows. If we
consider those combinations of outcome and potential surprise which will give the
individual the same stimulus as a given outcome with zero potential surprise, it is
obvious that the same stimulus will be imparted ezher by a more valuable outcome
with some degree of potential surprise, or by a less valuable outcome with some degree
of potential surprise. Thus the contours of the $-surface cut the east-west axis from
the south-west direction. The S-shape arises from the fact that no finite outcome can
compensate for, or be compensated by, infinite potential surprise (absolute disbelief).
Consequently, the contour lines must approach asymptotically to the outer limits
corresponding to absolute disbelief. It is also obvious that, in moving from south to
north across the surface, successively higher contours will be encountered ; conse-
quently, the contours corresponding to successively higher stimuli must lie inside one
another south of the east-west line, and outside one another north of the east-west line,
throughout their length.! On both the upper and lower sides of the model, the contour
lines are drawn directly on the $-surface when it lies above the base-plane, and pro-
jected on to the base-plane when the $-surface lies below it.

Any vertical east-west cross-section of the $-surface as it is represented in tbe
model would be a curve, concave to the base-plane when above it and convex to the
base-plane when below it. This would imply that the marginal intensity of stimulation
diminishes as the value of the outcome increases. This implication is purely a result of
the limitations of the material from which the model is constructed ; it is not required
by Mr. Shackle's theory, which assumes only that the intensity of stimulation is
orderable.

The ó-surface represents the psychological attitude of the individual towards all
conceivable combinations of possible outcomes and degrees of potential surprise.
To analyse his evaluation of a particular possible course of action, it is necessary to
introduce into the model his estimation of the possible outcomes of that particular
course of action, and the degree of potential surprise associated with each. It is
assumed with Mr. Shackle that there will be an '"' inner range " of such outcomes,
associated with zero potential surprise, and that outside this range successively higher
or lower outcomes will be accompanied by increasing potential surprise.

have seen that, if the supply elasticities are sufficiently large compared with the demand
elasticities, then the change in the terms of trade will be adverse ; but that in this
connection Mrs. Robinson's formula underestimates the likelihood of an adverse
change for high values of the elasticities of demand for imports and exports, and may
overestimate it for low values of these elasticities. Lastly, we have seen that for high
values of these elasticities of demand the change in the terms of trade will always be
smaller than the fall in the exchange rate.

VII.

One can but conclude this article on a negative note. In the foregoing paragraphs
we have taken only the first and perhaps most essential step towards a comprehensive
treatment of the problem. We would be wise to remind ourselves of the many simpli-
fications we have made. We have reduced the very large number of types of com-
modity in the real world to four only. We have taken no account of the import content
of exports. We have assumed that changes in the distribution of income have no
effect on the demand for commodities. We have left unconsidered all reactions on
rates of interest and on opportunities to invest. And we have made further special
assumptions as we went along. Yet with the help of all this simplification and of a
great deal of tedious, if pedestrian, mathematics, we have achieved regrettably little
in the way of positive result.

This I believe to be in the nature of the problem. It turns out indeed to be a far
more complex problem than the simplicity of Mrs. Robinson's treatment would
suggest. Nevertheless, so long as factors of production are not fully employed, it is a
real problem, and one which may have considerable practical importance. The
Keynesian nature of the problem should, I think, be emphasised. We saw in section V
that any classical approach was entirely inapplicable. However, the unfortunate truth
remains that as soon as we dispense with the classical assumption of full employment
in the field of international trade we find ourselves in very difficult waters. Possibly,
in the end, inverted commas may prove to be our only practicable means of support.

The advantages of experimental research, when adapted to the needs of economics,
are striking. Compared to traditional empirical research in economics the experimenter
has considerable control over the design of the markets within which his economic agents
operate, and he can exclude some influences from which he wishes to abstract while con-
centrating on others he wishes to study. Anyone questioning results within the experi-
mental framework is able to replicate an experiment performed by someone else and
analyze entirely new and independent data. On the other hand, the world of the experi-
menter is artificial and of his own design; so the extent to which experimental results
may be taken as a clue to behaviour in real life markets is uncertain.

The two conclusions on oligopolistic behaviour which emerge from these studies are:
the Cournot solution characterizes behaviour in incomplete information situations, and,
under complete information, a subject is more cooperative, the more cooperative is his
rival. It is not obvious whether these conclusions will obtain under more intensive examin-
ation, or how more comprehensive experiments will find them modified; however, they
are interesting results and suggestive of what might be done experimentally.

Such a sensitivity test is in some sense a type of validation of the curves drawn, but
more direct validations could be proposed. The indifference curves obtained could be
used to predict choices among commodities not lying on one of these curves. This could
be done by simple extrapolation or interpolation. Another possible attempt at validation
could be performed if a constant marginal utility of a common commodity could be
assumed and two sets of indifference curves would be used to predict the third set, as
Thurstone attempted to do.

A more interesting test would be to form pairs of individuals and put them together
in a barter situation with some fixed amount of two commodities and allow them to leave
with whatever division they agree upon. By putting their indifference curves together
into an Edgeworth box one could see how close they come to the contract curve. That is,
one would predict that in a one-shot situation they would form a division on the contract
curve and the actual division would form a test of the accuracy of the individual in-
difference curves. Alternatively, they could be started on the contract curve and any
movement away would be noted and would be evidence of the lack of validity of the
indifference curves.

Another attempt to validate the indifference curves by direct prediction would be to
make the appropriate assumptions to get numerical utilities and then these could be used
to predict choices. Any discrepancy though could be attributed to either poor indifference
curves or the invalidity of the assumptions made. "This topic will be explored in some
depth in a forthcoming paper (MacCrimmon and Toda [8]).

Most of the discussion above is directed to determination of indifference curves in
situations that an experimenter constructs. However, we might wonder whether these
procedures can be used in real world choice situations where preferences could be reflected
by indifference curves, for example, the bombs and bombers trade-off of Hitch and McKean.
It should be obvious that the emphasis on training, reflection, and checks on consistency
could be part of any consideration of preferences. Also, the complexity reduction tech-
niques based on admissibility can easily be used. This, then, only leaves the question of
whether the payoff part of the method is useful in real world choices. Note that as we
use it in experiments it is particularly effective because the subject will actually receive a
commodity bundle based on his positioning of the indifference curve. Clearly there are
many situations, not only bombs and bombers, in which we are not prepared to give the
individual one of the commodity bundles. This leads to the question of whether the payoff
part of the method is of any use when applied hypothetically—for example, ** suppose
after you draw the indifference curve we randomly select a combination of bombs and
bombers, if it is in your accept region we will give you that combination, if it is in your
reject region you get the reference bundle." Whether such hypothetical payoffs are
effective is an empirical matter, but in any case it is probably as good as any other pro-
cedure in these contexts. Since all important decisions involve a representation of prefer-

Viewed from an additional perspective, bargaining as a theoretical construct and
bargaining behaviour as an empirical focus play an important role in organizational
behaviour and organizational theory. In this regard, the research reported in this paper
can be viewed as relevant to several current issues in organizational behaviour and theory.
First, much of the recent work by Homans [6], Adams [1] and Weick [10] has indicated
the powerful role that the equity of a reward plays in influencing attitudes and performance
in organized settings. The role of differential attitudinal and behavioural results in a
bargaining task is central to this stream of work. Our results on the differential affect
toward the bargaining task and toward earnings generated by the power and information
variables generally support this stream of research and add to the task generality of
previous results. Second, an important issue in organizational behaviour and organiza-
tional theory is the relative value to be attached to increments in information available to
bargainers in an organizational setting. Our results, generated through experimentally
varying the amount of information available to a bargainer regarding the possible monetary
payoffs to his opponent associated with any given bargaining contract, are relevant to this
theme. Our data support the suggestion in the literature that under specified bargaining
conditions information regarding a counterpart's payoffs may possess negative value.
Third, the role of personal characteristics in determining the bargaining behaviour of a
triad is a critical area for research in organizational behaviour. We view the risk-taking
propensity of the participants as particularly relevant to understanding their behaviour on
bargaining tasks. Our results indicate that there are significant individual differences in
the manner in which high and low risk-takers handle information, power and communica-

negotiation regarding salary, duties, discipline, etc.) does generate significant differences

recently, organizational behaviour has been concerned with the behavioural and affective
consequences of the degree to which communication channels are ** open ", both vertically
and laterally, in an organization. Our experimental variations of the availability of
communication are relevant to the issue of whether communication necessarily increases
the profitability and/or the perceptions of satisfaction associated with bargaining.

CONCLUSION

We feel that laboratory simulation of organizational processes of the type described
in this paper is a useful but certainly not exclusive strategy for investigating bargaining
behaviour in a triad relationship. It does, however, seem particularly appropriate at

and their interrelationships. Based upon the findings reported here, our research is

III. CONCLUSION

We have shown that it is possible to construct a meaningful market model without
assuming that the decision maker possesses information which in most cases he does not
in fact have. The marginal-cost-plus policy adopted in this approach is consistent with
the desire to maximize profit, and we have shown that the stability of the model can be
ensured with a set of conditions that are not unduly restrictive. Moreover, the model

while we analyzed only the effects of a tax parameter, the results suggest that the effects of
other parameter changes will be just as determinate. Finally, one result on which we did
not dwell in the text may be stated here as a concluding comment. Since the choices
made by each firm under the rules specified in this paper are different from those which
the firm would make if it had full information about its demand function, and since under
the latter circumstances the profit of each firm would be less than what it could earn under
a cartel arrangement, it follows that the actual level of profit earned under conditions of
lack of information may be higher than that earned under full information. Thus,
ignorance is not necessarily the root of all evil.

very little difference to the results.

Conclusion

In this section I have used two alternative methods to estimate the period of the
cycles likely to be generated by Goodwin's model of cyclical growth. Both methods show
that with reasonable values of the parameters, the period is considerably longer than the
4 or 5 years of the typical recent trade cycle. A cycle with this period is only likely to be
generated if all profits are saved, if the capital-output ratio is very low (less than 2), and
real wages respond very strongly to a fall in unemployment. In fact the model as it stands
may be better suited to explaining the 16-22 year '*' Kuznets " cycle than the postwar
trade cycle.

4. CONCLUDING COMMENTS

In this paper I have discussed three quite different models of economic growth and
tried to show that in each case examination of the timescale provides useful information
about their behaviour. This is not altogether surprising, since some kind of time dimension
is implicit or explicit in our thinking about any real economy; and we should expect the
timescale of these models to be important for understanding their relationship to the real
world.

In the course of the paper I have made considerable use of numerical methods of
analysis, and in particular of numerical methods to solve differential equations which
could not be solved analytically. This technique seems to have been relatively little used
in recent economic literature, although similar methods were used in the 1950's to analyze
the behaviour of trade cycle models. While such numerical methods cannot yield results
of the strength which economists have come to expect, I hope that the present paper has
demonstrated that this capital-intensive approach can have considerable value.

5. CONCLUDING REMARKS

In this paper we have presented an operational method for generating production
functions exhibiting returns to scale which vary with the scale of operations in a pre-
assigned manner and having a preassigned elasticity of substitution which can be constant
or variable. We refer to such production functions as generalized production functions.
Some implications of several such functions for the behaviour of labour's share have been
explored. In addition, we have provided an illustrative example to show how the para-
meters of a generalized production function can be estimated by the maximum likelihood
method. This approach can be utilized quite readily in the analysis of the particular
functional form utilized herein and of other generalized production functions.

4. CONCLUSION

In his discussion of liquidity preference and portfolio choice as behaviour towards
risk, Tobin has been careful to emphasize that the mean-variance analysis must be regarded
as an approximation (e.g., Tobin [17], pp. 12-14). This paper has shown that even his
rather plausible simplifying assumption that the investor's subjective probability distribu-
tion has only two parameters is insufficient for deriving the indifference curve convexity
properties that facilitate the analysis of investor behaviour. Moreover, if there is more
than one asset, an analysis in terms of only mean and variance is not strictly possible unless
utility functions are assumed quadratic or probability distributions are severely restricted.

But the inability to obtain unambiguous a priori conclusions about liquidity preference
or portfolio choice behaviour does not diminish Tobin's contribution in emphasisizing
the importance of analyzing this behaviour as optimization under uncertainty. Rather
it emphasizes the need to develop empirical research in this direction.

The Measurement of Utility '

INTRODUCTION

In this paper we show how the utility levels attained by a consumer may be measured
exactly under idealized conditions. These conditions include knowledge of the trajectories
of prices, income, and quantities, and of the numerical magnitudes of certain elasticities.
The approach taken provides a ranking for all consumption vectors on the trajectory.

An analytical expression is given, showing the effects on the marginal utility of income
of changes in income and in relative prices. These effects depend on the income elasticities
of commodities and on the income elasticity of the marginal utility of income. A link
is thus provided between a number of concepts and parameters of consumer theory.

The result also lends itself to empirical application. Estimates of the demand
elasticities are available from many econometric studies. The less well known elasticity
of the marginal utility of income plays a role in intertemporal utility maximization. Follow-
ing Samuelson we show how it may be estimated from data on total consumption
expenditures over time.
